This place gets 4 stars because... Because... Ooh, dessert arrived.

I like that it's on the second floor, away from Haight St annoyances.

The server women also run the food.

So, this place is really just "A-okay." But these women work so hard. Give them 20%.
author: Kiai K.

description: Sneaky little restaurant upstairs on Haight. Yummy yummy in my tummy.
author: Shawn H.

description:
Great food, poor service. I took my friends from Austin back home to the Bay for MLK weekend. We spent a lot of time in San Fran, mainly because they had never seen SF before.

For dinner, we tried Ploy II. The specials looked great, I wanted to order more but I went for the Red Curry with a side of white rice. It was really good, it was spicy enough but in my opinion could of been a little more spicy. I like more of a kick on some things. One of my friends also got the red curry. The other got the Mango Panang Curry, which was also very delicious. It had the right amount of sweet and nicely sliced chunks of mango. We also had some Thai beers, I wasn't feeling those too much. Tasted like Coors, but if you like that then you'll have no problem.

However, the service was poor. Staff was very inattentive. My friends ordered beers and when the waitress came back she didn't bother to ask me if I wanted anything. I had to ask for a straw for my water, twice. Received our food, and curry sauce got spilled on my friends iPhone by the waitress. It was an accident but don't think she bothered to notice. Didn't really come around to our table much after that. It was also really cold inside. Windows might have been open or maybe it was the draft from the door wide open downstairs. Bring a jacket!
author: Jolene B.

description:
Ok so I wanted to give this place more like a 4 and a half stars but I'm feeling generous and truly I am fed up with all the expensive restaurants with no soul taking over the city these days...
This little gem is so romantic and unique: I love that it's upstairs in a charming Victorian house, I love the blue, I love the fireplace, I love that you can look down on Haight street but no one can see you, I love that the servers wear the traditional dress, I love that the waitress was so patient and accommodating when my gf asked for no sugar in her meal, I love to watch and listen to couples on their first date ask the most cliche questions (that was entertaining, he he...)
Now to the food:
*Delicious soup
*Delicious Crab Rangoon
*Delicious Duck curry (maybe could be thicker, that's the half a star I would take off)
*Generous portions
*Affordable prices

Goodness
author: Monkey B.

description:
This is definitely a SF family owned and operated experience - the restaurant is home style, you literally feel like you're sitting in someone's home. The food is absolutely incredible, great portion sizes, and nice employees. Support local! 

Must try the pineapple fried rice and pad Thai
author: Tyler K.

description:
OMG. This is the only time I have ever wished there was a ZERO STAR RATING. 

I've been here a few times and had always had a good experience which is why I decided to come again with a friend. For some reason, this time the food was pretty bad. Tasted weird, like old trash. I'm not exaggerating. Literally, like garbage. Both of our food. We told the manager, who I also believe is the owner and they just said ok and took it away. He put our dishes in the bus tub with all the other dirty dishes. No apology, no other offer.

When we asked for the check, we saw that we were still charged for the dishes. (We only took 2 bites). We asked them to take it off the bill as it was inedible. He refused and said we ordered it so we must pay. I said no way, we were willing to pay for our drinks but there was no way we were paying for food we didn't eat. He didn't understand that concept so instead of arguing more we just said we will pay for it but then we would need the meals then. 

And this is what we watched him do:
HE WENT TO THE BUS TUB, DUG OUT OUR FOOD AND BOXED UP OUR DIRTY FOOD. 
Never in my life have I ever seen this. Was this really happening? Was he serious???!!! Yes, he was. He bagged it & really tried to give it to us! We told him we saw him and he said we still need to pay for it. No freakin way. We left cash for the drinks and...

Me: that is disgusting. I'm going to Yelp you!
Him: oh yeah? Well I'm going to Yelp you!!

WTF.
author: Linda C.

description:
Go to Ploy II for a cozy, nicely removed, tasty experience, that lets you take your sweet time in an uncrowded environment. If those conditions meet your restauranting criteria, you've found your place. 

It's not bustling as it's located on the 2nd floor of a Victorian building near the beginning of the Haight gauntlet at Shrader St. Do you avoid restaurants with hip crowds drawn by edgy menu designs and elderberry cocktails like you avoid excited people passing out religious flyers? Perfect! Ploy II offers a lovely yet humble dining experience akin to your home dining room, plus they only serve straightforward drinks like Singha beer. The service is quick, willing to answer any questions, and very friendly.

The food is unpretentious, generously portioned, and tasty. I can especially speak for the Pad Thai and Pumpkin Curry which were very satisfying, flavorful, and excellently priced. 

Charming choice for a sometimes uncharming street. No gimmicks here.
author: Chelsea B.

description:
My first experience with Thai food. One of my friends asked where I wanted to eat and suggested Thai and Ploy II off Haight. I replied, "Is it clean?" She looked at me, laughed and replied in her French accent, "Yes. It's clean. Crazy Americans." 

I think back on that moment fondly because as a bit of a germaphobe, living in SF was torture for me. The Haight certainly isn't the cleanest street in SF but armed with my hand sanitizer, I loved it just the same. 

Ploy II has awesome food. I'd always call ahead to make sure they had their fresh spring rolls available. Those things would go quick. 

They also deliver, even their ice cream!!! You have to try the fried banana and ice cream.
author: Jolie K.

description: I've had a decent meal at Ploy II in the past, but was disappointed with my meal tonight. I ordered the Panang Curry with chicken and there was not a single vegetable in the dish...not sure if that was intended. The mango in the mango sticky rice was unripe and flavorless. Not sure I'll be coming back with other great Thai food in the area.
author: John H.

description:
Me, my wife and a couple of our friends went here for dinner for our birthdays, me and my wife pretty much share a birthday (one day apart in the same year). 

I made a reservation earlier in the day. When we arrived this place was packed old school looking down town house off of Haight st (it was a Saturday night) waitresses/servers were hustling like crazy; so crazy that I had to flag one of them down to get seated (we were standing around for 15 minutes after my reserved time) I have a lot of patience so everything was ok up until this point. We get seated, we select our meals. 

Me and my buddy chose the Spicy Duck, which was amazing! My wife picked the roasted Duck (it was even better then the spicy duck) my friend's wife and husband were originally going to order Pad See Ew but the waitress said, "We're out of that noodle." Devastation sets in, she says "You're really out of that noodle?"..."Yes." that's the only reason they wanted Thai food that night, they said they were thinking about it all day lol.. Well my friend didn't order anything at first because of it. And then decided on some type of garlic chicken that tasted pretty good. 

I'm giving 3 out of 5 stars because the service throughout the whole evening was horrible, I personally felt as if our table was ignored and we had to flag the waitresses for water/drink refills numerous times throughout the evening and I had to ask for the check eventually because we weren't even in their radar far as service goes. Pretty much the service is 1 out of 5. The food is good which makes the 3 star average. When we left my friend said I would have rather gone to Best of Thai down the street ha..
author: Jason V.

description: I've been coming to Ploy 2 since 1996. They have the best Pad Thai I've ever had except when in Thailand. The staff is so friendly. Highly recommend!
author: Heather S.

description: Thai food is one of my favorite cuisines, and the food at Ploy II is absolutely delicious. Since I love vegetables, I ordered extra and they were fresh and perfectly cooked. The service is superior and very friendly. The restaurant is located upstairs in an old house on Haight Street and has interesting views from the window tables. I highly recommend this delicious and inexpensive restaurant!
author: Gerry B.

description: Amazing authentic Thai at reasonable prices. The salmon in special spicy sauce is the best dish I've had in a long time. Spicy doesn't always mean spicy but this sauce will have you reaching for your hot tea or Thai tea to quench the fire. It comes with underseasoned broccoli and carrots, and a nice touch - crunchy fried spinach. I'm trying that at home. Other notable dishes - prawn Pad Thai, Lemon Chicken and flavorful Won Ton and Tom Yum soups. I only wish we lived closer.
author: Patina W.

description: Basic, don't expect anything fancy or phenomenal. Service was great and the space is cute. Reviews may be a little inflated.
author: Kate S.

description:
Finally found a Thai place that is mostly satisfying in San Francisco, after 2 whole months! I had been meaning to come here ever since I got here, but it's a little bit out of my way along Haight street so it never happened.

Anyway, after being repeatedly disappointed by the weird/lacking flavors in Pad Thai from every Thai place I've tried here (Soi Gow, Best of Thai Noodle, Tawan's Thai, King of Thai Noodle), I decided Pad Thai wasn't the entree to try at Ploy II out of sheer conditioning although normally that's my basis to judge a Thai restaurant.

Instead, I ordered Pad Kee Mao with chicken and fresh spring rolls to go. Pad Kee Mao was very flavorful and just spicy enough, but I did need to add a little bit of soy sauce to it because it was lacking some... sodium, for lack of a better word. I'm really not one to ever add salty ingredients on my food, so that was a novel moment for me. So all in all, Pad Kee Mao was decent, but I probably would not get it again, and may zero in on the Pad Thai next time. Oh, but the star of the meal were the fresh spring rolls, which I totally was not expecting! Usually they're made with shrimp and these ones were vegetarian so I had my doubts, but it was so flavorful and the sauce it came with, a blend of fish sauce (I think) and peanut sauce, definitely completed the meal. Will come back here again before I leave!
author: Jenn L.

description: Old school Thai upstairs. A nice escape from Haight street. Tom yum soup, summer roll, Padang curry . Vegetarians say yes!
author: Ed H.

description:
Wow this place is such a rip off. I had a bunch of friends visiting from another country. They said they wanted Thai food. I looked up reviews on yelp since we were on haight st and thought we would give this place a try. 

We had a party of 5 and we ordered 4 dishes and a few rice plates. When the bill came the total was $64 something. I thought that seemed like too much. My friends who were tourists wanted to just pay, but I looked looked at the bill and saw that she sneaked in a 20% gratuity charge! I think she thought we were all tourist.

She just added the amount at the bottom where it said "base" above tax. When I questioned her about it, she was really rude about it, saying oh yeah I added gratuity, just pay this amount you don't have to tip. So I argued with her saying.. places usually charge only for a party of 6 or more, you can't add this charge! Do they think this place is the Cheesecake Factory or something? She knew I was right, so she took the bill back and changed it. 

She brought it back and we didn't want to tip at all, but we didn't have exact change. Grr.

Other than that part, the food was pretty delicious. I would come back just because the food is delicious.
author: Jessica S.

description: Sadly disenchanted.  I wanted it to be what my 90's era memory said it would be...it was just okay Thai, nothing too special...not special at all, in fact, but not bad. Oh well...at least now I know I do have access to great thai where I live in Seattle area.
author: Renee S.

description: Gods I love this place. Their delivery and food is wonderful. Also, not that 'best of thai noodle' has gone out of business, this is about the only reasonable place to find wonton noodle soup...
author: Amy T.

description:
I love this place. In fact, I'm ready to declare that it serves my favorite Pad Thai in all of San Francisco. The noodles are a great consistency, and aren't too greasy.  They also have a tofu satay appetizer, which is quite yummy and not easy to find.

My one complaint is that I wish they'd use an online delivery service. Having to call, place an order, and recite your credit card number over the phone is tedious, and makes me feel uneasy security-wise. Having cash on hand is always an option, of course, but Grubhub is so much easier...
author: Janna M.

description:
Loved this little Thai place tucked into what was clearly an apartment before the Zoning Gods waved their wands. You have to walk upstairs to get to the restaurant, but that just means you'll have a nice window-side view of the Haight denizenry. 

We had the pad see ew and pad kee mao. Hefty portions and the noodles were cooked perfectly (lots of "wok energy," as my people would call it). Add a dash of the spicy vinegar that you can ask the pink-frocked ladies for, and it's pretty much a perfect meal.

Place has just enough kitsch and prices are pretty average.
author: Kevin L.

description: This place is great! Inexpensive and reliable Thai food. My favorites are the green curry with chicken and the pumpkin red curry, both with brown rice. They also deliver within the neighborhood which is awesome.
author: Sara S.

description:
Delicious delicious thai food. I tried the drunken noodles to go, and it was amazing. The waiting area is a little cramped, but she gave me a cup of tea as I waited. 

The restaurant in itself looks cute and has older decor. Not a bad place to stop by at all! So far it's been some of the best thai food I've had in the city.
author: Sneha P.

description:
by far my favorite thai restaurant, we live less than a block away from and eat here at least 3-4 days per week! It's affordable and soooooooo delicious!!!! 
Our recommendations: 
yellow pumpkin curry - to die for!!!
chicken satay - perfectly seasoned
bbq beef - yuuuuum
beef and broccoli - yuuuuuuuum
author: Virginia F.

description: If you like shrimp and spicy food. This is the place for you! The vibe is awesome as well, located on the second floor with a great view. The wait staff is busy yet friendly. My favorite Thai restaurant in San Francisco!
author: Wanning J.

description: I felt like I was someone's living room, being served their favorite foods. Nothing fancy. Everything delicious. This review need not be any longer.
author: Ryley P.

description:
Good for both take out and sit-in. Very family run / authentic feel to the place and staff. Overall quite friendly and a good spot for a chill meal.

Food quality is 4/5. Almost every dish I've had there has been quite good, but rarely ever blow-your-mind good. One of my top 'hood carry out spots
author: Milan T.

description: We are just wandering around the area and will settle as long as more than 5 tables are filled. This one is hided on the second floor of a tiny building and we heard ppl talking -- can't be bad if ppl can find their way here right? I tried the mango curry with prawn (or shrimp) and it is better than I thought. I generally don't like my curry too sweet and they did a good job combining my favorite mango flavor in a curry and not over sweeten it. Will definitely come back again if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Sophia H.

description:
Great delicious authentic Thai food at an affordable price. The Pad Thai is great as well as the Duck Curry (Yellow). I can't do too spicy of foods of the spicy duck was so flavorful that i sucked it up. Love the attire. Love the fact that the restaurant is in what looks like an upstairs flat on Haight. Love the silver cauldrons that they serve the rice in! Also love the mango sticky rice.

Will be coming back time and time again :)
author: An-Nhien L.

description: I was very hopeful given the 4 star rating but when I got here I was extremely disappointed. I ordered the pad thai and couldn't eat more than 1 bite. It was disgusting and the fish sauce was over powering. The service was not the best either. I won't be returning.
author: Sarah W.

description:
Hits the spot when you are craving cheap Thai. The pad thai and spicy basil were good and the portions are pretty sizeable as well.

The delivery is clutch, perfect for foggy, cold, or wet days in the city. Or if you live in the haight and you are high and can't get up from the couch.
author: Charles H.

description:
My sister orders food for delivery here a lot so we decided to get dinner from here last night since we didn't want to leave the apartment. We ordered Tom Yum soup, pad Thai and sticky rice with mango and had it delivered to us. An older Thai lady came with her young son to deliver us the food. After I signed the credit card bill and closed the door, the lady knocked on our door again and said that tip was not included in the bill. I was taken aback by her brash manner but I still apologized and gave her some cash for tip. I went downstairs afterwards to pick up a package my friend had left for me at the front door of my building. The package was there when I came home but it was now missing when I went to get it. I looked over and saw my delivery lady holding my package so I chased after her and asked if she took my package. She said she found it at the door. I pointed out that my name was on the package and she gave it back to me. 

I cannot believe how unbelievably rude and unprofessional this restaurant is to employ this woman who was caught committing mail theft red-handed. The food is good but there are plenty of good places for Thai food in SF.
author: Chi N.

description:
was aimlessly walking around the haight and stumbled upon the plastic sign that said restaurant upstairs.

Inexpensive thai food but flavorful and homey. The waitresses were very nice and pleasant. Tried the spicy basil chicken (get the ground chicken, not sliced) and it was medium spicy. tasty over fresh rice. The green papaya salad is perfectly tangy and a large serving for just $6.95

Chicken satay appetizer is also a great size (5 skewers) with a tasty fresh peanut sauce that does not taste like JIF, and a lovely cucumber salad on the side.
author: Jane P.

description: Delicious food, and the delivery person even returned because she noticed that she had forgotten to give me my ice cream! I hadn't noticed yet, and she came all the way back to my house without me having to ask.
author: Alex F.

description: So-so....  Tacky decor.  the fried spicy fish was good.  The pumpkin curry was sub-par and has lots of peas and slightly undercooked veggies.  The egg rolls were not great.  They abandoned our table towards the end and we sat with our credit card on the table for 15 minutes.
author: Marisa G.

description: Great thai food in a classy, home decor.Victorian that's been outfitted as a restaurant. Think comforting, not upscale. Tried several dishes and they were all very tasty.
author: Will D.

description:
The food was perfectly acceptable - not bad, not great. I do like the setting: an old victorian that looks like the turned it into a restaurant overnight. It's very unassuming while still being comfortable.

The price is okay, the biggest drawback is that it's on Haight (yuck). Service is very prompt and attentive.
author: Megan S.

description:
To summarize, great food, horrible service.

I recommend picking up to-go only. If you eat here, they don't time well, leaving one person without food for 20 minutes, don't ever refill water, and never come by the table.

It's super cute inside, so if you're ok with ordering a beer to quench your thirst, you'll love it. 

They're really vegan friendly, and you should try the drunken noodle, yellow curry, and spicy combo platter. Yuuuummmm.
author: Nick W.

description:
Here's the story with this spot. The food is legit. The service is whack. I have been to Ploy II four times. I do not know where Ploy I is, I assume it exists and this is not a ploy to get me to think they are good because they merit multiple locations. 

Whatever you do, or rather don't do, is order delivery. It's a hot mess. 

(Granted I live a few blocks away and I have no business ordering delivery, except that my sweatpants are on, which means I'm done with Haight Street; so no walking through tourists, 'street kids', real drug dealers, like I'm Adrian Petersen.) 

I order, and the nice lady tells me: '15 minutes.' That's awesome. Except its not based in reality.  

40 minutes pass...well I guess I should call in make sure I gave them the right address. "It's on the way." Cool, no worries. Things happen, people like Thai food, place gets busy, I get it. 

1 hour 20 minutes pass...call back again make sure their delivery person is not stuck in walking-down-Haight-street traffic. They assure me, "it's on the way." Like is it physically 'on the way?' or is it 'on the way' the way that retirement is 'on the way' for me in like 50 years. I can pick it up. I will put pants on at this point. Hungry. "No, its not here, it's on the way." Okay, well.

1 hour 45 minutes...now I'll just call back because I miss our conversations. Hi, it's me again. What's that? You want my phone number and address again. Why? Don't act like you don't know me. We are besties. What's that, you say, my food is 'on the way...' okay..do you happen to know where Ploy I is? Perhaps I should call home base and see if they can deliver Shrimp Pad Thai 4 blocks in under 2 hours.  If it's 'on the way' then your delivery man must be at Milk Bar drinking toddys with the boys. 

Ten minutes later...I call..."We are closed"....No, Wait! It's me! How have you been? "It's on the way" hangup.....

Finally, after another ten minutes passess, a really nice girl comes to the door with our food, she asks if we have already ate, which is sorta funny actually. She was apologetic. And also I realized she was a server that we had when we came in to eat a couple times before. 

As for dinning-in, there seems to be a problem with understaffing. I waited 25 minutes for a drink one time, now that I think about it, it's possible our server took the order, then left to deliver some food that was already an hour-and-a-half late. 

I want to like this place a lot. It's quite yummy. But if you are going to tell some one 15 minutes, be honest with yourself. Or call me, and be like "Hey dude, I am preempting your next phone calls by telling you now your order will take 2 hours" Cool, pants on...walking down to get it myself. 

humbug.
author: Adrian K.

description: Set in the wondrous aesthetic of a San Francisco living room, Ploy II's cuisine is no ploy. Surprisingly affordable and delicious with a great variety across the menu. Don't ever be afraid to play it safe and get the Pad Thai.
author: Alex C.

description:
For authentic Thai food at a great value, Ploy II is definitely my go to Thai spot in San Francisco.

Of all the Thai options in San Francisco, Ploy has stood out above the rest as the most authentic and flavorful of the bunch. Both for takeout or dining-in, you will not be displeased with your experience.

My personal favorite is the Duck Curry and the Yellow Curry with chicken. Additionally, the Larb Gai salad is one of the most flavorful and refreshing salads I've ever had - it is a must order. The veggie spring rolls are also amazing, but they seem to run out ALL THE TIME!

The restaurant itself is not fancy and is located on the second floor of a walk up inside the Haight. It's a cozy location with a homie feel. The staff and service are great, but the food speaks for itself. Give it a try!
author: Justin O.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in the world. How do you people not come here every other night? The carafe. I live in LA but dream of Ploy II as often as you should go. The carafe.
author: Mary C.

description: The cashew nut tofu on a sizzling plate is the most delicious and tasty dish I have ever had anywhere in SF....not that I have been to that many Thai/vegetarian/vegan places...but I have been to several. I can't wait to go back for more. Plenty of sauce, veggies, and tofu. 5 stars without the music, 4 stars with the music. Whatever happened to quiet conversational atmosphere?
author: Diane D.

description:
Ploy continues to be the all time best ever Thai restaurant anywhere. Maybe even better than the ones in Thailand!

Last week we tried the green curry chicken and frankly we were amazed....it may be our new favorite....right after the truly incredible pad Thai with prawns.

Family run and never  disappointing....6 stars!
author: Jim S.

description:
Great service but Thai food so so
Best laub salad but entrees so so not hot enough temp and spice
author: Jennifer L.

description:
The service here is bad. REALLY bad. Sure, it's cute that you're eating Thai food in someone's living room, but I'm not sure that the proprietors of this restaurant could effectively walk and chew gum at the same time, forget seating you promptly, taking your order, bringing the meal and the check. My girlfriend and I had sit-down meal here last month and the extents to which the host and our sever went to completely ignore us was almost comical. Mind you, this was a mid-week meal and it was not crowded. The food was fine, albeit unspectacular and we chalked up the bad service to an off night. 

Tonight (Tuesday night at 8 pm), we ordered take-out and it was an even bigger fiasco. We placed our order at 8 pm and they told us our food would be ready in 20 minutes. When we arrived, the host ignored us again. Eventually, we got their attention long enough to pay (they managed to get that part right), but no one came out with our food. 10 minutes passed and no one came out at all. When the host came out, she said our food would be right out. 10 minutes later, same thing. After 45 minutes, we learned that THEY HADN'T GIVEN OUR ORDER TO THE KITCHEN. No apologies even though it's almost 9 pm and we are STARVING. After an hour dealing with these dum dums, we finally got our food. 

The service at Ploy II is crappy and the food is alright. There are so many alternatives in the neighborhood and it's just not worth dealing with disorganized, apathetic people.
author: Ben N.

description: Good late night option in the Haight. Food was fresh and affordable. Place was a bit dingy/musty smelling. But they accommodated our large group really easily.
author: Andrew K.

description:
6 months ago, I hated Thai food.  I had tried it time and time again and was just not impressed. It got to the point where I would decline to go out to eat with friends if they were going to get Thai.

A couple of months ago, my boyfriend forced me to go to Ploy II because he loves Thai food. Now, Ploy II is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. I literally don't know what I would do if they closed tomorrow and I would not have their duck curry in my life anymore. I feel like that says it all.
author: Jenny S.

description: Great food, but I called at 10:00 and they were open. Asked for to go pick up and was told they couldn't take an order even tho they close at 1030.
author: Jacob M.

description:
Your typical, hole in the wall, best kept secret. Complete with tacky decor and staff uniforms.

Located on Haight Street, but I wouldn't say its the easiest place to spot. You will find it if you are looking for this place in particular. 

I've had a couple of the noodle dishes and the curry and they were great! Service is a kinda unpredictable but far from awful.
author: Andreena S.

description: Delicious Thai food! So So good. Everything I've had was amazing. It is a weird location because it looks like you are in someones house. But it is very good Thai food.
author: Lily C.

description:
Great food for very good prices. Service was really slow, and a ten minute wait turned into 40 minutes. 

Nevertheless...

Thai iced tea - nothing special, the usual
Mango Panang Curry - DELiSH! Mmmm mango. We got it with beef.
Drunken Noodles - I've definitely had better. This one just tasted like pad see ew. 
Prarim - some dish with chicken and peanut sauce over spinach. SUPER good but heavy (then again, most Thai curry dishes are heavy).
Pineapple fried rice - super greasy, but pretty freaking delicious.

They ran out of eggplant on a friday night. Sad face.

I would DEFINITELY come back though for these prices! I ate waaaay too much for one sitting. It was an uncomfortable walk back to the car.
author: Stef S.

description: Excellent food!! Service was alright, and the atmosphere was unusual, but the view over Haight street is nice. The food is worth the visit.
author: Lydia I.

description: New manager - discriminates against people with disabilities.  Does not allow service dogs.
author: Aine O.

description: Thank you, Ploy II, for making an excellent dinner for my in-laws! Everything was very tasty - green curry, panang curry, appetizers (chicken satay, corn cakes), prik king.... mmm. Fast, efficient delivery.
author: J S.

description: I remember this place being better than this... We had the pineapple fried rice, chicken curry dish, sour soup and they were all ok, nothing special. I could get it at any other thai place. It is nice for its neighborhood, but i drove all the way here to check it out and realized i can go to my near by places and get the same/better value. Cute, authentic interior decor though. Not bad but did not do it for me.
author: C A.

description:
*3 stars for the restaurant experience, but 4 stars for the takeout version!*

My boyfriend was raving about this place. All I heard for weeks were "You HAVE to try the Drunken Noodles!" We ordered a take out of the Drunken Noodles, and it was really good! They must use some sort of peanut oil to stir fry... because it smelled delicious.  I definitely recommend it. I wanted to actually sit in at Ploy II, so we finally went together on a weekday for dinner.  It's a little hidden on Haight, located upstairs in a what  probably used to be a flat. 

For a weeknight at 9pm, the place was PACKED. We didn't have to wait too long to be seated, but the tables are pretty cramped together. I usually don't mind the tight seating in restaurants. As long as the food and service is good then I can deal with a little crowding. 

The service was pretty slow. We asked for water, but they seemed too busy with the other 5-6 tables. We asked for water again, but it also took a while for them to bring it to us. The waiter didn't check up on our table to see if we were ready to order either. We had to patiently wait, and then ask her to come over. We ordered Eggplant Curry and a Papaya Salad. Both of which were pretty good. I liked the aroma of the curry, because I can definitely taste the distinct spices and flavoring. The proportions were a little small, however. 

I realize the place was pretty packed, but I would've enjoyed the experience more if they paid equal attention to every table. If you want tasty Thai food, order from Ploy II but take it elsewhere to get the most out of it.
author: Linda T.

description: Solid thai restaurant on Haight. I stopped by here on a Sunday night right before closing, so there were few others in the restaurant. My boyfriend and I split the tofu red curry. The portion was very big- enough to feed the both of us and we had leftovers to take home. The curry itself was pretty average- I've had worse, but I've also had better. The waiting staff was super nice even though we stopped in right before closing. I would definitely stop by here again.
author: Flora J.

description:
I was initially confused about the name, but now it all makes sense:

Ploy II is this restaurant's ploy to drive you you crazy with slow service yet surprise you with delicious food--making both your tip and Yelp review terribly hard to calculate.

It was honestly probably the slowest service I've ever experienced. It took 15-20 minutes for a server to take our order, and another 15-20 at the end to get our check. In between, however, we enjoyed a delicious meal of veggie curry puffs (more like flat samosas), crispy tofu with peanut sauce, Penang curry, and Ploy Vegetarian. 

Definitely worth checking out, but pack your patience.
author: David Z.

description:
Loved our food here, lovely view. 
Clean yr bathroom!
author: Coco J.

description:
I wanted to try something different off their lunch menu so I went with the Silver Noodle Prawns - Pan fried prawns sautéed with egg, onions and silver noodle served with steamed rice. I requested this dish spicy.

Minutes later it was ready. The prawns were perfectly cooked tender and delicious. The silver noodles full of flavor and spiced to my satisfaction.

Good portion too...
author: Gary E.

description:
Great little Thai place tucked into what appears to be a former apartment. My boyfriend and I stumbled upon this place after spending a day exploring SF. The fact that it was late and we were starving maybe means my perceptions of this place are biased (and I admittedly don't know much about other Thai places in the city).. but I'm still willing to vouch for Ploy II as a rather solid place for good Thai food. Especially if you enjoy the feeling of dining in some stranger's living room.

(PS- on the second floor, so it's nice for dining while overlooking the street, but not wheelchair accessible)
author: Alice C.

description: The staff is mildly nice, prices are good, the food came out quickly and was hot.  Tasty food, little oily.  I would definitely come back.
author: Jill A.

description:
This is definitely my favorite Thai place in the Haight, if not SF.  What can I say the food is amazing, they are reasonably priced considering it is the Haight.  I always get take out, but this is a great place to sis down and perhaps sit by the bay style window to watch the passersby traffic on the Haight.  Even more so, Ploy II is housed in a traditional San Francisco Victorian and nicely decorated with traditional Thai decor.  
Some of my favorite dishes are
Pumpkin Curry
Mee Krab
Papaya Salad
Peanut Vegetables

I hear the chicken dishes are also good, but since I am a veggie I can't say for sure.  Although, pretty much everything I've had here is spot on!  Oh and a major bonus for me is they have brown rice.  I highly recommend this place if you are in the Haight already, since parking can be tough.
author: Molly M.

description: A hidden gem. Very typical Thai setting, quiet and confortable. The food is something else, try many dishes and share.
author: Guillermo D.

description: Ploy II is just so wonderful.  Their food is delicious, and comes in gigantic portions!  Their restaurant is set in a second story converted apartment, so it really has an adorable homey feel...literally. All the staff are incredibly accommodating. Service is fast, prices are really reasonable for the quality and quantity of food. I love this place and will keep coming back!
author: Alyssa A.

description: I got the curry noodles with chicken and it was amazing!! I would eat here every week if I lived in San Francisco!
author: Rachel B.

description: This place has great food! Only reason I'm giving it 4 starts is because they don't start doing deliveries until 5 and they can be a bit rude. But other than that love the food there
author: Andrea P.

description:
Pluses:
Took a reservation for 10 1 hour before reservation time on a Sunday.
The interior is really warm and intimate - we are pretty sure it was an apartment turned into restaurant (you have to go up a flight of stairs, and there are rooms).
Food was pretty decent and quantity was very decent.
Pad See Ew and Prawn Fried Rice = classics and very good
Thai Iced Tea - probs like a 3/5 stars

Minuses:
Service. Pretty slow. 
Everything is in Thai on the check, which would be fine if we cross checked with a menu, but as youngsters who can not yet afford Credit Card Roulette, the check process was a huge hassle. Since everything was in Thai we didn't see that gratuity had been added already (something you would assume for a party of 10, but it is not in the menu). We had to ask 2 people just to confirm that gratuity was added, and at first they said it wasn't. I had to clarify what the $26 dish was doing right above the total. She had to confirm it with someone else. I mean.. this is pretty standard stuff. We would have paid an extra $26 if they had not clarified this with us. Very disappointing.

Doesn't mean I'd never come back though, just a note to be aware.
author: Adele Z.

description:
Dude. A solid Pad Thai and Larb Gai with very healthy pours of red wine and cold beers. I'm sold. Love those ladies, regardless of their decor/signage choices.

And you eat in a living room. How awesome is that?
author: Andrew L.

description: This is our favorite favorite place on haight street. It is the most authentic Thai food in San Francisco. Their mango panang curry, beef chow mein, roasted duck, pork fried rice, and a full craft of red is our usual dinner. The service is wonderful. All the ladies work very hard and are always happy to serve you. (Not to mention so cute and funny) We end up going home with a nice bag of leftovers. Mmm sooo good the next day. Hands down best bang for your buck!
author: Sarah S.

description: Solid Thai cuisine and delivery in my neighborhood. Miles and miles better than "Worst of Thai" down the street. Friendly and prompt drivers (although I'm within 6 blocks so I'd be shocked if they lagged). I get the thai fried rice w chicken and Tom Kah w prawns on the reg. Dinning in is a little bit of a trip. Odd decor, somewhat dated but everything that winds up plated can't be hated.
author: Kareem C.

description: Ploy is wonderful! Tucked away in what was a second floor apartment in the heart of the Haight. Charlie and Sunee are amazing hosts and boy can they cook! Try the prawn salad, vegetable red curry and spicy tofu appetizer. Delicious!
author: Laura L.

description: Came here yesterday ordered the Tom Kha Talay Noodle soup it took very long to come and it was just overwhelmingly sweet. Had to ask for some fish sauce and lemons to fix it to make it at least decent to eat.  Plus-they gave a lot of shrimps and Calamari  Con- there was barely any noodles. All over service was decent maybe they were having an off day. So 2 stars.
author: Betsy X.

description: Very good food, very, very inattentive staff even with curry spilled on my phone, by waitress. Plan on waiting for any kind of service, at least 30 minutes.
author: Lauren R.

description: I was there last night with a friend, i don't usully like Thia food much but this place was amazing. We order Calamari Salad the my main course was garlic prawns so yummy. Those beautiful waitress with lovely smile and very friendly service. I'll be back on Next Tuesday.
author: Ercan V.

description:
Yum! Solid Pad Thai. One of the better ones I've tasted in SF

They've also got this sizzling vegetable dishes (I think it's a special) that is excellent!

Located upstairs (can be hard to be missed, so look for the sign and watch the address number).  

It is like a house (living room/dining room) transformed into a restaurant. I'm pretty dang sure it was someone's living quarters before. Cute, cozy, and wonderful.  Great to people/street watch if you're sitting by the window. Great place for a date!
author: Connie H.

description:
When I travel, which is often, I love to try out different Thai and Indian (my two favorite foods) around the country.  My favorite Thai used to be Tommy's Thai in Denver.  Now my favorite is Ploy II.  I have eaten here multiple times now and have never had a bad experience.  Everything I have tried on the menu is delicious, full of flavor, and surprisingly affordable for the quality.  I do not claim to be an expert on Thai food, it is just what appeals to me.  What I also love is the warm ambiance of the restaurant. It would seem that it is simply a converted home/apartment, and as a result it has a very homey feel to it.   

The servers have always been very nice, and the overall service excellent.  A meal at Ploy II never disappoints.  I highly recommend the Spicy Fish, Pumpkin Curry, and their Thai iced tea.
author: Scott R.

description:
My group of friends call this place "Living Room Thai" as they have done nothing to hide the fact that you are sitting in the living room of what used to an apartment.

This is my go-to Thai restaurant.  It is tasty and just enough spicy.  My favorite is the Veggie Green Curry, and I have a hard time passing up the corn fritter appetizer.

Good food for a reasonable price.  Good for lunch (they have a lunch deal with a deep fried triangle thing and soup with the entree) or dinner.
author: Tia B.

description: There isn't a Ploy One? Maybe it's because of being on the second floor? Hmmm... it's curious. Upon further research... ploy is a paste ingredient. So take it as the sequel to the Paste. Take it as a ploy to get you in the restaurant as the 2nd is always the best in the series (see: Empire Strikes Back). I love this place. It's a slice of city living that could care less about trends. All it takes to kick off the charm is that it's in an old Victorian on Haight Street, and it's on the second floor. And they haven't really remodeled the home so it maintains the feel that you're in a house. Came here nearly a year ago so I shouldn't speak to much other than the environment, the quaintness next to a fire place with a few friends and the order of a carafe of wine, and solid Thai food. Not much good Thai food in SF, so this would be my top choice because of the environment.
author: Jon A.

description:
Went to Ploy II recently with a friend and had a pretty average experience. The service was good, but we wanted to order an appetizer and soup to start and then keep the menus and still decide if we wanted anything more. Apparently this is atypical and confusing for the waitstaff, as every few minutes someone would come over and try to get us to order. We were not looking through the menus, they were just stacked on the side of the table. We had already explained to several people already that we were OK for now but may order additionally after the appetizer/soup, but we just gave in and said we were done ordering. If we were still hungry, we'd go somewhere else.

Got a bowl of Tom Yum with Chicken. On the menu it said this would "Serves 2-3 Persons" and the waitress confirmed that one bowl would be enough to split between the two of us. (NOTE: This is the reason we wanted to hold onto the menus, in case the Tom Yum was not enough for both of us) 

"Serves 2-3 people" might make sense with some explanation, which was not provided. It came out and was definitely *NOT* enough even for just 2 people for a meal. It could serve 2-3 people as an appetizer, in that they would each have a small cup of soup. Anyhow, it was good soup. Also got some fresh spring rolls as well. The food was quite good, just difficult to understand portions so we essentially just ate 2 appetizers when we thought we'd be getting a full meal. Unfortunately, this was not communicated by the server effectively, and being constantly harassed about still having menus lead us to having a skimped meal and venturing elsewhere to satiate ourselves.

All in all, good food. Could come here again, but would likely try a different new place first.
author: Tim K.

description:
I was initially skeptical of this place  -- upstairs in what feels like an apartment converted into a restaurant (I think its actually that) it feels strange climbing carpeted stairs evoking a sense of: "this could be awesome" or "oh my god, what did we just get ourselves into?" Promptly greeted (and seated) by an elderly thai woman in traditional garb you know immediately that she means business. Looking around, you quickly realize people are enjoying their meals quite thoroughly, as you chuckle at the hand-drawn signage on the wall reading "We have the right to refuse ANYONE service." (really?? I don't think that's quite legal) but anyway -- to the food:

Awesome food! Spring rolls were excellent. Fresh, cilantro-filled, best spring rolls of my life. Fried pumpkin: AWESOME. Too much food if anything, but that's okay in my book. Roasted duck over spinach, just what I wanted. Authentic, fast, inexpensive delicious thai. And, I mean it, inexpensive. $12 for the most expensive entree. $3.50 house wine and Singha beer. Great food; interesting experience. Don't be thrown off by the entrance -- a fine staple of the neighborhood!
author: Alicia R.

description: I've been coming here for about 5 years and it's my favorite Thai food in the entire city. The food has never been less than amazing and the restaurant is so cozy. Favorite dishes are ploy vegetarian and any of the curries.
author: Lucas W.

description: My absolute favorite thai place in SF. All the noodles are fantastic, my favorite are the drunken noodles. The curries here are delicious, too! The staff is nice and the feel is generally great! Highly recommend.
author: Alma A.

description:
Like many other restaurants on this street, they're all at least decent. I really like Ploy II because of it's random location and great food/prices. It is kind of romantic I guess if you're seated by the window so you can view the street from up top and there's a cute single flower or candle on the table.

LUNCH SPECIAL!!! I think it was about $7 for my vegetable tofu yellow curry with rice and soup. It also comes with a little wonton. I really liked the variety of vegetables I got in my curry. I've also tried their pumpkin curry during dinner, but sadly it wasn't as good as koh samui's. Still decent though. If you like chicken wings definitely get the basil wings! Reminds me of the ones back home at siam. 

Gets kind of busy during dinner, but I don't think I've had to wait for a table. Give it a try if you're in the area.
author: Stine H.

description:
This place is a hidden gem. You wouldn't notice it if you walked by because it is upstairs and doesn't have great signage but their food is some of the best thai food i've ever had. The people are also very nice, the service is really good, they are so sweet and if something is wrong with your food, they will re-make it. Take-out is fast. 

Recommend the chicken satay, fresh spring rolls, tom kha, Red curry, yellow curry, panang curry, green curry, pad thai, pineapple fried rice, vegetable param, spicy eggplant
author: sasha h.

description:
If the food wasn't pretty good this place would get 1 Star on Service alone.

The lady and I went on a quiet afternoon for a late lunch. There were only 3 other tables and 2 servers were on staff - yet it took over 20 minutes to even get our drinks. 

Our appetizer came out 1 minute before our food did (so it was cold by the time we got to it) and after putting the plates down we didn't see our server again until we had finished eating - 20 minutes later! 

I had to walk the check to the back (where cashier is - in the kitchen) so we could get out of there. 

No thank you's, no smiles, nothing. You'd think after 10+ years on Haight they'd have their act together...
author: D C.

description: Delicious! This was honestly probably the best Thai food I've had. I will absolutely be coming here again, but the food was, albeit, a little overpriced. Still worth it, and the veggie options are great! Mm.
author: Samiha H.

description: We eat here a lot partly because it is within walking distance of our house, but we also really like the food. It is not our absolute favorite restaurant in the city, but definitely high up on our list. Lots of vegetarian options (remember to ask them to make the food without fish sauce and also without MSG) Delicious food, friendly staff, nice vibe, decent prices, and we usually get our food pretty fast, even during busy times. When we have friends visiting who like Thai food, we almost always take them here and they are never disappointed. Definitely recommend it to others!
author: Terry M.

description: Delicious and reasonably priced. Upstairs -so quaint and quiet on what is a busy street. Great sauces, great lunch special comes with big appetizer and delicious soup!! I have a nine-month-old baby and they give us a highchair.
author: jennifer o.

description:
The food at Ploy II is delicious.  For me it just doesn't get any better than "Spicy Fish", which is a whole snapper in a spicy-sweet basil sauce.  It's also a very intimate setting.  It's situated above a shop on Haight St, and the 2nd floor view of the street below is really cool.  

The servers dress in traditional Thai garb and they are very nice people.  

One disclaimer:  Don't go here if you're not prepared for a nice, easy-paced sit-down meal.  This is not an In-n-Out.  Take someone you care about here and focus on good conversation and just relax.
author: Drew B.

description: a group of my friends decide to come here after hearing about it for six years.  we are immediately approached by the waiter named jeff, who smells like a mixture of axe and sweat.  He brings us thai style ice water and some thai coca cola, which taste a lot like american coca cola. anyways, food came out really quick and it was very flavorful. We ordered too much food that we decided to ask the waiter, Jeff, to join us. He agreed and we ended up eating with the waiter. He told us stories about his life and how he always wanted to be a rich drug kingpin or a pharmacist, I forgot which one.  in the end he decided to not charge us for any of the food. (What a nice guy.). He even gave us all a ride home in his van.  free food, a ride home and we made a new friend.   what more can u ask for?
author: Nelson C.

description:
My housemate and I have eaten here twice.  The food is excellent and the dishes are quite different from most places.  Sizzling platters are tops.  The atmosphere is cozy and quaint and we love sitting window side.  The only downside and why I gave atmosphere  a 3.0 is the unnecessary noise of loud pop rock music playing behind the uncontrollable loud voices of other patrons.  The latter can't be helped by the owner but the music could be turned off when the place gets busy.  It ceases to be music and just becomes added noise.  
Otherwise this is a great little hideaway for an inexpensive night out.
author: Mary M.

description: My favorite is the panang curry, so delicious! My friend got the veggie version and I got the chicken and they both were delicious!! Their yellow curry is good but the panang is my favorite!
author: Ellie R.

description: Ploy II is great! I've had a hard time finding above average Thai food in the city, but this place was great. It felt like we were dining in someone's home, not a restaurant which I thought was a nice touch. We had pumpkin curry, pad thai and a veggie dish and loved all of it!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Finally: good thai food. Yummy yum yellow coconut chicken curry and sweet and sour pork. Prices are fair and they deliver far and wide from Richmond to Mission. 

Try to be patient though, they take forever to deliver and the woman on the phone is kinda rude if you have to ask her to repeat what she said as she takes super fast. But worth the wait as far as I'm concerned.
author: Alita M.

description:
Review for delivery only.  We've ordered from Ploy II probably a dozen times.  Being 11 blocks away, delivery is usually super fast.  Food always arrives hot and is very flavorful.  Solid way to satisfy a Thai craving.

Favorites are Tom Yum soup, Yellow Curry, Panang Curry, Green Beans, Praram, Garlic Prawns, Seafood Combo, Pad Thai, and Spicy Tofu Combo.
author: Christina M.

description:
Every few years I give Ploy II a chance to prove they've improved their food.  

Dinner:  prawns in black bean/ginger sauce.  Not only was there not one black bean, but they are still putting celery in their food.  Bland and cold.  Rice, $1.50 extra was not only cold but dry and hardened at the edges. 

I am a neighbor and would be a regular customer, but  this food has lost it's former rich flavors.  

Sorry, but that was my last visit.
author: Susan L.

description: Ok, I know I give a lot of five star reviews but seriously, only if I think it deserves it, plus, I usually only go somewhere I'm referred to, especially when traveling. The three of us ate here after a long day of meetings and shared everything, there wasn't a dish we had that we didn't all gush and gasp and smile over. Cute little apartment-like restaurant...nothing more to say, I can't wait to go to SF again if only for a meal here!
author: Katie K.

description:
This little gem was such a great find! The outside doesn't look like much, I was expecting a hole-in-the-wall, but it's actually really cute, and the food was great.

We had the fresh spring rolls, I had pad thai and my bf had red chicken curry. The curry wasn't very spicy, but I asked for my pad thai extra spicy, and it was perfect. Everything was really tasty!
author: Alyssa S.

description:
Ploy II, where do I begin to extoll your virtues? 

I've been coming here for great Thai food for around 7 years now. I've celebrated birthdays, mourned breakups, shared secrets, tried new things and deepened many a friendship over the consistently fabulous food of Ploy II. Step inside, go up the stairs, and your journey towards sensual foodie intoxication begins...

Start with the Green Curry Puffs. You'll thank me silently as the incredible combination of spices, vegetables and deep-fried joy explodes onto your tastebuds. Although I enjoy a variety of Thai dishes, I almost always get the Pad Thai here. It's just too good to pass up. The curries are great, (especially the Panang and Pumpkin), and if you want it spicy, they deliver the goods! Although I don't eat meat often, the chicken, beef and seafood dishes always look fresh and colorful, and they smell delicious!

As I dined here last night with a girlfriend, I got to thinking about how grateful I am for this place. In the turbulence of everyday life, it's nice to know that here is a place that has stayed true to it's virtues - low prices, wonderful recipes and incredibly polite and efficient waitstaff. There's never a wait, the service is helpful but never overbearing, and even when it's crowded, (which happens often), I have never once felt rushed. Here, they treat you like an honored guest and keep you coming back for more. Thanks for being awesome, Ploy II!
author: elizabeth d.

description: Best Thai food in the Haight!  Make sure to try their Pad See Ew, you won't regret it.
author: Sean S.

description: The restaurant is located in a Victorian, it looks really cute from the inside. Mango curry they make is super delicious!
author: Maria O.

description: Delicious, fairly priced, and good quality. The service is always good. I like that it's upstairs in an old house. The front windows have a little view of Haight street.
author: Michelle W.

description:
I hate to give this place only 3 stars, Ive been eating here since 1996 and this has been one of my favorite thai restaurants ever. And I love thai food. Back in the day, the mama who worked here was a wonderful loving woman. She knew me as a teenager, wacthed as I grew up, got married and had a baby. She fed us excellent food and would have never tolerated anything less.

Within the past 2 years, the service has gone downhill big time. I live in the Richmond and call for delivery. And have had a lot of problems with their service. Once they took over 3 hours to deliver, and then after I had already cancelled my order, they still came with ice cold food and insisted I take it and sign. I refused and got a call back from sove man yelling at me that he cannot cancel my credit card so I have to take the food. The next day I found they had charged my card 3 times (accidently?!)  and it took several days before they all dropped off.

I didn't eat there for a year, but the cravings got the best of me and I tried it again. No real problems but the food is not as high quality as it was before. Then, one night I ordered and they said my credit card was denied. I had no other form of payment, and even called the bank to see what was going on. The bank said they were running it as a debit card, and it was a credit card so they were denying it/ I tried to talk to the manager and she hung up on me! I called back and she hung up again!

So I am now in search of another thai place in SF that sells their yummy Thai Corn Cakes and Silver Noodles with mixed veggies. 

I'll probably end up caving and ordering again someday. But it has never been the same quality as it was in the 1990s. 

And if you eat there, it's upstairs in an old victorian house on Haight St. Beautiful place, and if you're lucky you can get a seat at the window to people watch. But if you're pushing a stroller or in a wheel chair, or just not very mobile, you're out of luck since the only way in and out is a narrow stairwell.
author: Venus S.

description:
Actually came here for dinner after getting my purse stolen in SF earlier that day. I was feeling pretty bummed and in need of some GOOOOOOD food for a much needed pick me up. And this place totally fit the bill! 

I loved the feel of the decor and the fact that it looked like the transformed inside of home into a restaurant. The waitresses wear beautiful outfits and are really hospitable. I always order chicken curry from thai places and theirs was delicious!! I definitely hope to go back next time I'm in SF!
author: Cristina M.

description: Warm welcoming and cozy restaurant. The pad thai dish is my favorite. Everything taste just like grandmas home cooked meals. I recommend this place for sure!
author: Fiona S.

description:
20-October, Saturday
I've been here more times than I am able to count since I moved to the area, but haven't thought to write about it since it is just second nature for me to come here when I am in the area and when I am in the mood for eating good Thai food, at a decent value. (which is often!) I had just spent hours on end enacting the role as a tour guide, and scouring through Amoeba for music before coming to dinner, so we were starving for something hearty. 

The outside of this place is VERY understated, one could easily walk by without noticing it if the proper precautions weren't taken to look out for the dinky sign. The interior of Ploy II looks like a Thai temple threw up in the mouth of a painted Victorian Lady. The restaurant itself is situated near the Golden Gate Park side of Haight-Ashbury on the very top level.  Upon entering the front door at the lower level, you are confronted with an immediate flight of stairs, which creates little intimate nooks and pocketed places within the restaurant as the tables flow around the circumference of the circular donut-shape of the restaurant. At first glance it feels like you just stepped into someone's home restaurant, but it is bigger than it looks. The heavily decorated interior is rather charming: coffered walls & ceilings, to all the playfully hilarious hand-made signage. Some notable ones included; "we accept the right to refuse service to anyone," to "you will be escorted off the premises if you start experiencing an allergic reaction" (just kidding -it actually didn't say that but I could honestly infer that's pretty much what was meant)
 
The waitresses are all dressed in traditional Thai-style shuttle woven brocade dresses, and scurry around with much efficiency.

Really fresh spring rolls, and my green coconut pumpkin curry was mild in spice, and a medley of warm savory-ness, without skimping out on any of the calamari, prawns, and mussels. I had a friend visiting from Australia, and he had the exact same dish except with chicken and more spicy (red curry) and he seemed to also enjoy his meal. 

Perhaps I underrate Thai places, because growing up with these flavors from my mother/ grandmother's home cooking has given me a critical tongue. Otherwise, I would gladly come back to this place.
author: Ty T.

description: Love the Prawns Param and adorable Victorian house location with street view!
author: Kristen M.

description:
Discovered this place in the past few months, and it's become one of my favorite Thai restaurants in the city so far.  Really yummy Thai food with inexpensive prices.  Pretty nice that it's in the Haight area to, so after eating, you can wander the shops, grab some coffee, and visit GG Park.

My favorites so far are the duck curry and deep fried pumpkin as an appetizer.  Those dishes definitely sealed the deal to make me a return customer.
author: Thuan N.

description:
Cosy, cheap, and damn good. 

On Friday, the Upper Haight's restaurants all boast long lines. Citrus Club, the Alembic, and others are swamped with hungry pre-gaming patrons.

If you're looking for a nice alternative without the line - try Ploy II.

Fairly hidden, with minimal signing, Ploy feels like you're dining in someone's home. Essentially you are. They've reconstructed an old victorian and transformed it into a solid Thai restaurant.

We only had a five minute wait and they seated us right by the window so we could see all of the random Haight drama while we dined. I ordered the cashew tofu, and finished each bite.  Messily spooning the sauce onto my rice, well after all of the tofu and veggies were gone. The cashews cooked within a spicy chili sweet sauce and lightly fried tofu and fresh vegetables were superb. With rice for everyone and even an appetizer, we were wowed, when the total for each person came out to be about 10 dollars per person (including tip!)

One of the best Thai spots in the Haight. The menu is extensive and everything tastes  - just made. I'd highly recommend browsing through some of the regular patron yelp reviews before going though. Their menu is so overwhelming, that some sure thing Yelp recommended dishes could easily slide Ploy II into a secure standing as a stand-out dinner or lunch spot in the Haight.
author: Jessica T.

description:
When I called up my girlfriend a few weeks ago to invite her to dinner here, she asked me, which Ploy? To which I replied, Ploy II, on Haight. In the back of my mind, I wondered where the other one was...

Naturally, I later yelped it. Strangely enough, Ploy the First does not seem to exist. Things that make you go hmm...

Perhaps its name is just part of Ploy's big grand scheme to maintain an air of mystique. Unless you KNOW to look for the place, you'll miss it, as the entrance is a narrow staircase leading up to the restaurant itself, situated on the top floor of an old Victorian flat. It's a nice retreat from the hippied-out streets of Haight-Ashbury, and a homey way to enjoy the comforts of Thai cuisine.

The food is definitely a step up from King of Thai or Best of Thai Noodle down the street (ick, that place's pad thai makes me nauseous). If I'd write home about anything, it would be their lemon chicken which we always traditionally get only at this place, though I've never tried it at any other Thai restaurants. The crunchy seaweed does it for me.

Scratch that, at Ploy II, you already are home. That's no mystery :)
author: Kate V.

description:
Not cool. 

We call to place an order and are told it will be "an hour" for delivery. I called after an hour and a half and am told the food had not been made yet, they could not tell me when it would be ready - no apology, no estimate. They asked if I still wanted it. Clearly not. Good food, thus the bonus star, but don't expect delivery if they get busy. And don't expect to be treated well if they forget you.
author: Marie J.

description: Generously adding a half star. 2.5 stars is as best as this place deserves. The food was actually not bad. However the service here was hands down the worst I have experienced in the city. 10 minutes to get a menu, 20 to get a beer, over an hour to get our food. Granted there was 6 of us but that is just unacceptable. They didnt even bring us two appetizers we ordered. And to top it off they turned out the lights partially where we were sitting before we paid our check as if they were trying to rush us out from a taking too long. I will not be coming back and I don't recommend this to anyone.
author: Derek S.

description:
I always get myself some shrimp pad thai and a thai ice tea.

I love this place, it has a great ambiance with the Thai masks on the walls and the general feel. It's a little cramped, but it's understandable since it's on Haight Street and there's no room to expand.
author: Karma B.

description:
BEST PAD THAI!

I used to work about two blocks away from this place and would come often for lunch. You can easily miss it because it is located inside an apartment building and the sign is not too visible. Pretty cute inside, just feels like you're having lunch at a friend's place but with many others too. I always get their Pad Thai and it comes with two slices of orange and a potsticker. 

Here's the funny thing, they tend to give you more when you order take out. I'm not kidding! Me and my brother both made this observation on several visits. Enjoy!
author: Elaine L.

description:
My friend and I had lunch here. I am very thankful that my friend introduced me to this place. The restaurant occupies a narrow space on Haight Street. The restaurant decor is comfortable and friendly. We had a nice view of the street from our window table on the first floor. The food is clearly the star of the show here. We ordered the beef salad, garlic shrimps and rice. I later ordered some red curry too. I am a fan of Thai food, so it was nice to see bold, authentic Thai flavors. The beef salad spiked with peppers, mint, and lemon juice makes your mouth come alive with a perfect blend of hot, sour, salty and sweet flavors. The red curry with its subtle flavors was divine and tasted just perfect with the rice. The garlic shrimps dish with large succulent shrimps in lots of garlic was fantastic too.

I will go to eat here whenever I can.
author: Sabya M.

description:
2.75 stars.

Don't you hate it when something OH so good goes OH so bad?

I had the longest wait here last night. Not for a table, but for everything else!

Waited 20 minutes to order.
Waited 20 for plates and silverware.
Waited 10 more for food.

Waitress passes by and asks, "Did you get anything yet?"..UH..by the looks of my table with NO food on it, YES I did get something: MORE HUNGRY!

After taking my first bite.....I forgot about waiting. Our beef salad and Green curry were amazing. Good to the last drop!

Soon after I did more waiting and by the time I got the bill, I was too upset to have dessert. I canceled our sticky rice and mango, paid in cash and got the hell outta there!

Note to self: The Haight is starting to get a little rough after dark. Not worth it even for good Thai!
author: Lily M.

description: Oh Ploy II, how I hoped  you would be a good quick take out place for me but it just wasn't meant to be.  I left work late tonight so I figured I'd just pick up quick takeout  wherever I passed that had a parking space.  A car pulled out of a space a few doors down from Ploy II as I was driving down Haight.   I'd never been to the restaurant, but pass by frequently, and have been curious so figured this was a good time to give it a go.  I did a quick check on yelp so figured with four stars, I can't miss. Bleh!  Got the pad see ew with chicken, my go to thai takeout dish, and am so disappointed. I probably would have stopped after the first couple of bites if I wasn't starving. It wasn't horrible but so bland that it isn't worth the calories!   The most bland pad see ew I've ever had. I seriously considered throwing it in a pan and adding soy sauce but figured that would make it worse.
author: Heather G.

description:
Just got takeout from this place, and yum!  The red curry was my favorite.  Don't let the description of the various curries worry you -- the red really isn't all that spicy (and I'm a certified spice wuss).  The pad see ew was delicious as well and had a great balance of chewy noodles, sweet sauce, and vegetables to soak up all that deliciousness.  

I wasn't a huge fan of the tom kha soup, which was sad, since it's typically one of my favorite dishes (and the litmus test by which many Thai restaurants are judged).  It was a little bland for my taste, and at one point, I bit down on a chunk of whole lemongrass... oops.  Also, the sides of rice are pretty small -- you'll want at least two of them to go with one order of curry.

All that aside, the rest of the food was really delicious, and the delivery was fast -- especially on a Friday night!  I'll definitely order again.
author: Laura R.

description:
The place is ok. A bit little if you have a kid in a stroller. We had fried noodles as appetizers, then a chicken soup and a salmon with spicy sauce.
Waiters are friendly and come checking on you sometimes.
author: Cesare R.

description:
It's a Thai restaurant literally hidden on Haight  
It wasn't too crowded but by the end of our meal it was pretty packed with people. The food was good but it didn't blow me away
Pricing was definitely reasonable in terms of portion size 
Great selection and variety

i've definitely had better thai food in the South bay, but if I'm ever in the area I'll come here again 
I liked their tea, straight up thai tea and was bummed when they didn't have fried ice cream
author: Tammy K.

description: Definitely check this place out if you are craving Thai food while shopping on Haight. It's a funny little place on the 2nd floor that overlooks the street, I ate here a few weeks ago and watched the guy across the street paint graffiti on the walls lol. I ordered the yellow curry which was delicious and a side of cucumber salad. Will definitely be coming back to try other dishes!
author: Alice S.

description:
Damn!!  I've been eating here for literally a decade, and have always been happy until the past 4 or 5 visits.  Everything about their food, service, etc. has gone down hill.

Today we came for lunch and were 1 of 3 tables.  Because their Thai Iced Tea is often way too sweet, I made sure to order it with LESS coconut milk, explaining that the past few times it was too sweet.
Of course it comes FULL of coconut milk, exactly the same as my partners.
I ask her to put some more tea in it to make it less sweet, she brings it back with virtually NO coconut milk AND about a 1/2 cup of SUGAR in it.  Whaaaaaaat?  What part of *too sweet* requires added sugar?  Also, Thai Iced tea is typically black tea with coconut milk added for sweetness, NOT pre-sweetened  tea with coconut milk.

So my partner is vegetarian, and last time we ordered, he got the Veggie Panang, which I tried and LOVED.  Great mix of curry/sweet and of course, full of veggies and tofu.
This time I decided to order that, but with beef, and instead of getting veggie panang with beef, I literally got 8 slices of beef and curry, with not a SINGLE PIECE OF VEGETABLE in it--a huge scoop of white rice, curry and meat and NOTHING ELSE ( no onions, nothing!).
Come on now...are veggies really that expensive?  It's not like people who chose to eat meat have chosen NOT to eat vegetables.

Last time I got the Pad See Ew and it was the same thing.  TONS of darkly sauteed noodles, some gravy and some beef, 2 slices of onion and maybe 3 pieces of broccoli--seriously chintzy.  Again, just because I am not a vegetarian doesn't mean I'm a meatatarian.

Again, it pains me to write this review, but we've had such consistently bad experiences for the past 2 years (them adding extra meals to our group bills: adding tip and not telling us, hoping we'd double tip: getting incomplete or incorrect meals: providing substandard food, slow service and spartan vegetables) that I can't let another day go by without a well earned review from a LONG TIME customer.

I'm so sad, too, because they were my favorite Thai Place in the 'hood.
author: D C.

description: Everytime I've eaten at Ploy i've enjoyed my food. I highly recommend Pak kee mow dish...so yummy.
author: laura q.

description:
I love the location, it's so quaint. It's upstairs in a light blue Victorian house overlooking Haight. I went on a Saturday afternoon around lunchtime, and it was not crowded at all, so it was a nice quiet atmosphere for lunch. I enjoyed looking down on the street while eating. 

Our server was very polite and professional, and never let our water run out. Service was very quick. 

The food was tasty, especially the little appetizer soup (some sort of green curry soup). 

Extremely affordable, about $13/person which included a thai iced coffee, appetizer, and entree for both of us. I would return.
author: Kevin H.

description:
Best Thai food for the price in all of SF. I used to live unreasonably close (for my pocket books sake) to this place, but I loved every minute of it. All of the delivery folks were incredibly nice, as they said nothing about my messy apt, and always delivered the food in a timely matter. I do love a variety of Thai dishes, but their Pad Thai is perfect, keeping me coming back. As some of the reviews mention, on busy nights, they get kind of slow on service. If you're really that concerned about it, I recommend calling ahead, and ordering the food to go, to then find a less bum ridden place in GG park to have your meal. On weekday evenings I rarely had any problem with the timeliness of my food. 

Bottom line: I will always choose this place over any other of the Thai offerings on Haight St.
author: Sarah Ann B.

description:
REALLY GREAT THAI FOOD!

If you look at my reviews on  Yelp, you will notice I am brutally honest (so I will give you one star if I don't like the place). This service was amazingly fast, food was delicious (a little bland), but for the price and service, I think it's a great place to get thai food. Would definitely recommend. The service was probably one of the best I have received, since the food came out so quickly!
author: Daisy J.

description: I decided to take some friends from out of town to get some good Thai food in the Haight. God I wish we had just kept walking. We sat down and ordered, loved how it feels like a home. We ordered our drinks. Didn't get those for 15 minutes, had to ask the server to bring them. 50 minutes later after two separate tables that had come in after us got their meals, we finally got one dish out. We waited, and waited, and waited for the other ones. We ended up just taking our meals to go since they were all cold anyways. The food itself wasn't anything special, because at least that would have made our almost hour long wait somewhat redeeming.
author: John T.

description:
I've never noticed this place before because it looks very much like someone's house. The comfy atmosphere was very unique and something I am surprised doesn't exist more in SF.

The food was one of the best Thai meals I've had since I went to Thailand. The red curry and panang curry were my favorites and the crab noodles (basically pad thai with crab) was a close second. I wasn't a huge fan of the garlic shrimp, which was a recommendation from the waitress, so definitely make your own choices instead of letting them pick for you.
author: Megan S.

description:
Came here after a long day of bar hopping and I was pleasantly surprised by the quality and quantity of the food! I had the vegetarian red curry and it came out in a correll bowl which I thought was interesting dinnerware for a thai restaurant, but the food inside was delicious! The curry was rich and flavorful with a strong curry flavor and a good kick at the end. It was loaded with lots of different fresh vegetables including broccoli, eggplant, cabbage and bamboo shoots. There also was a ton and I could only finish about 2/3 of the bowl. I like to judge thai restaurants by their red curry since it's my favorite and this one is making me crave it really badly! 

I also tried several appetizers including an interesting corn cake thing. They were all pretty solid, but the star was my curry. Yum!

One last tip, the servers like to tell you that you only have a 2 minute wait, but 2 minutes = ~20 so don't get too excited!
author: Mabel L.

description:
The Haight continues to be the place for good eats @ great prices.  Ploy II is a great little spot for some tasty Thai.  They've got a menu chalk full of the usual traditional Thai goodies...there are curries aplenty.  Of note, the red curry definitely packs some heat.

From what we've sampled there, our tastebuds have been properly tantalized.  Just be aware that when you go, the 2nd level space that the restaurant occupies is definitely close quarters...You're literally elbow room with fellow patrons...But if you took MUNI to get there, you should already be properly pre-conditioned and you'll be just fine.

Ploy II...yet another spot that makes me have all love and no hate for the Haight.
author: Justin L.

description: If you want basic Thai food, this is the place. I did a pick-up order because my roommate recommended the pad thai which I thought was again, very basic. I definitely did like their sticky rice dessert which was pretty good; however, it's really hard to mess up this dish. The menu is quite vast for a typical Thai place which I like because I really hate it when they just have your typical dishes. One complaint though and this is a common theme throughout San Francisco but not many places have Thai Boat Noodle Soup. In LA, this was a staple at all Thai restaurants. The decor of the restaurant is not that great. The restaurant is located on top of store. It's basically a former house that they converted into a restaurant. You can tell once you go to the register. It was kind of ghetto looking. However, the staff is very nice and the food is descent. For a quick Thai fix, I would definitely come back to try their other dishes which might actually be quite stellar.
author: Gary I.

description:
The strange smell in the restaurant was kind of a turn-off. Couldn't quite put my finger on what it was, but it was not ideal. In their defense I was rather hungover, so I think my senses were just being overly sensitive that day.

I ordered the yellow chicken curry, and it was pretty good. But my favorite still remains to be Marnee Thai, with Chabaa at a close second. My boyfriend unfortunately did not enjoy the chicken dish he ordered, no doggy bag necessary.

I love that it's overlooking Haight St, but I just feel like they aren't using the space's appeal to its full potential.
author: Katie S.

description:
I went here with two girl friends. It's upstairs so kind of tricky if you're not familiar with the place.
Everything was great. I got pad see ew, no eggs, with tofu, no fish sauce and a cucumber salad. I LOVE cucumber salad and theirs was delicious.
It's a little quiet inside but everyone is really nice. Definitely going there again since I live like a 5 minute bike ride away.
