author: Justine L.

description: Took Lauren on a date there knowing nothing more than a second floor venue. Inside looks like a converted apartment and has a family service feel. Prices are very reasonable and there was an extensive list of specials, one of which we has. . Mango panang curry. We also had soup appetizer with prawns that was an amazing way to start the meal on a cold night. The place has a good feel and overall we both enjoyed our meal, but 4 stars for slow and inconsistent service. We didn't have utensils and were ignored for about 20 minutes while waiting for a check. Nevertheless, we will for sure return.
author: Tim L.

description:
corn cakes (with sweet chili dipping sauce), vegetarian tom yum soup, and vegetarian mango panang curry, shared family style amongst three people. BEST IDEA EVER. mango and panang sounds like a weird combination, but by the end of the dinner, we were lapping up the rest of the curry like poor orphans in Oliver Twist...a sight indeed.

I learned that the corn cakes weren't gluten-free the hard way...but they were amazing at first bite. i will defnitely be making my own gluten-free ones at home, though.

also, we ordered steamed rice for two, and it ended up being enough for four. who doesn't love extra rice? seriously awesome, dude.
author: Helen I.

description: I ordered the Thai Fried Rice and it was delicious, but I was extremely full I could barely finish all of it. We came here because I tagged along with some officers (student government) and I got to know them a lot better. One of them has a boyfriend who works part-time there so we also got complimentary corncakes, which we forced her to take home. It was pretty good, but our portions were really big the two of us (the girls) could barely finish our meals. Although, the dude finished his. It has such a homey atmosphere there that I was thinking about falling asleep (Tired from officer duties)! And very quaint. Of course A+++ service, if only he could walk just as fast in the halls at school T.T
author: Millissa T.

description: This place is a bit random. You may have a hard time finding it as it is on Haight street and is on the 2nd floor of a house. If you get past that you'll find that the food is very tasty. I had my usual pad see ew (sp?) and pad thai. Service was good and staff were friendly.
author: Carlos A.

description:
For some reason, their silver noodles with mixed vegetables dish really speaks to me.  It says, "eat me for I am best."  Besides it, though, Ploy II's other dishes are good as well.  I've had some good duck curry and fried rice/noodle dishes.

Beyond the food, Ploy II has done a pretty good job of differentiating itself for being one of three (!!!!) Thai restaurants on one (!!!!) block of Haight.  It's that only one that is upstairs and looks kind of like a converted apartment, and their waitresses wear Thai (or at least Thai-inspired) outfits.  Make sure to grab a table by the window, so you can watch the ridiculousness of Haight unfold below you while you dine on delicious pad thai.  Mmmmmm.
author: jon y.

description:
if you're in the mood for Thai, this is a really great place to go. 

I especially LOVE the way they make their pad see ew. 

This place also doubles as a really cute date spot, since it feels secluded from the rest of Haight street, AND it gives a nice view from above if you score a window seat.
author: Tiffany S.

description:
I went here with a group of friends(5 of us total) after B2B.  First of all, service was awful.  They brought out one person's food quickly after ordering, and then another one about 10 minutes later.  The rest of us got our food almost an hour after ordering, and we had to ask if our food was still coming(I don't think it would have come if we hadn't asked).  I could have gotten  over that if the food was good.  I got Pad See Ew, which is pretty much my goto dish when I can't decide at a Thai restaurant.   First, it was similar to Pad See Ew, but it was different than I've had at every other Thai restaurant that I've been, including the many places I got it in Thailand.  Secondly, whatever it was, it was bland and was a small portion.

I'm seriously dissapointed, I'd heard such good things about this place.  I'll probably give it another shot, and hope it was just a fluke.
author: Ted G.

description:
I. LOVE. THIS. PLACE.
I tried Thai food for the first time at this restaurant and I got the good ol' Pad Thai and Thai tea and lemme tell LET ME TELL YOU HOW BOMB THIS STUFF IS
I tried thai tea at another cafe and I didn't like it but I decided to try it here and it is sooooo good. 
The service is good, the food is good, the price is good. 
I CAN EAT HERE EVERYDAY
author: Victoria D.

description:
Came here with a large group of friends. We ate family style (BEST idea ever)-- and everything was really good- appetizers and all.  They have tons of vegetarian and seafood options. 

Only reason it doesn't get 5 stars is because I got take-out recently and didn't fall in LOVE with the tom yum soup-- I found that it had very little in it other than chicken. Also they do not deliver until after 5PM! I know that's pretty standard, but I was really sick and needed soup and absolutely didn't want to leave the house.. But I did, for pick-up, knowing that I would be happy with my meal.

SPARKNOTES:  Your standard Thai food done well / right for a great value.
author: Roxane W.

description:
I've had thai food at this place before. So I can say with confidence that the food quality is 3-4 star quality.

However, I ordered thai food on a friday for 4 friends at 7:45pm. I live in NOPA, so hardly a far takeout drive for them (I can bike to this restaurant in 10 minutes).  We were told the order would be here in 45 minutes. Reasonable enough for a Friday, right?

1 hour and 15 minutes later, I call them and ask about our order.  They appear flustered and say they're really busy and that it'll take at least 20 minutes more.

20 minutes later and here I am still waiting.  I want to like these guys, but it'll be my last time doing delivery with them. I'll plan to stick with my tenderloin go-tos Lers Ros and Sai Jai instead.
author: Joe L.

description:
I absolutely love their Pad Thai..... delish!  My boyfriend and I order their pad thai, two thai iced teas and then we pick any other dish.  The noodles are a must though.

They are affordable and easy to find right on Haight Street.  

The only downside was that they are up this super narrow stairwell.  I was nannying so I would have to get the stroller up this ridiculous staircase.  Totally worth it though =)
author: Jessica J.

description:
Siam Lotus across the street is closed on Tuesday, so I gave Ploy II a try for lunch.

Food was very slow coming out of the kitchen -- it wasn't the waitstaff's fault -- and it was below mediocre. The soup was inedible.

What a mistake. Won't go back again.
author: Crabcakes C.

description:
I ordered the chicken with peanut sauce, spinach, red peppers and cabbage. I have to say that this peanut sauce was some of the best I have had in a while, runny enough to lay over my rice perfectly. It was sweet, smooth, peanuty and spicy.

The place is a little weird to me. I know people like the house atmosphere but it was a little cramped and kind of like 1980's. Not a biggie though. The food was good. I tried my friends pad thai and it was on point as well with moistness and great tamarind flavor.

I'll be back.
author: Krista N.

description:
Went to Ploy II for an early-ish dinner. Even though it was a party of four with no reservations, we got seated promptly, and at the table of our choice (upstairs). Maybe because it was early (6ish)-  the restaurant was pretty empty. The restaurant itself has a cozy, friendly feel, and the servers were all polite and prompt.

Food:  We ordered the spring rolls, mango curry chicken, chicken fried rice, and shrimp pad thai. All the dishes, save for the fried rice, were quite good. The curry was not overwhelming the chicken, and the pad thai had a generous amount of shrimp. The fried rice was - fine- but nothing to write home about. Overall, this is a quaint little spot with good, solid food and service.
author: Sonia M.

description:
Ploy II and Siam Lotus are both within 2 blocks of my house. Siam Lotus is ever-so-slightly closer, so it wins out when I'm feeling energized enough to walk to collect my comfort thai food. What really sets Ploy II apart is that they are willing to deliver food to my door. That's right, I am so lazy that I get them to walk it 2 blocks to my house. They even let me pay on credit card. This is a lazy person's dream. Thank you, Ploy II for enabling me to indulge my most hedonistic food fantasies. 

Fortunately, the food is always delicious. I am spoiled. Oh, I have also eaten in the restaurant, and that was good too.
author: Lara C.

description:
You know sometimes you get that craving for a certain type of food, but you want to have it now and not have to wait forever to get it. That's why it's always nice to have a restaurant that is close by, but still inconspicuous enough where you don't have to wait too long for your food.

Ploy II plays that role for me when I am craving Thai food and feel too lazy to travel that far. Ploy II serves up some really good comfort food in the Haight Ashbury, especially during an extra cold San Francisco night. 

Plus Ploy II also satisfies the inconspicuous requirement, as it is located upstairs. Once you enter the restaurant, you feel right at home as the waitresses (dressed in Thai clothing) are warm and friendly. 

In terms of food, you can't go wrong with curry. I always go with the red curry because I like mine spicy. This is definitely not Thai spicy, only American spicy (if you need that extra kick be sure to speak up). I've tried the roasted duck curry, chicken curry, and seafood curry. All are good choices, but my favorite is definitely the roasted duck curry. I usually get the curry plus the Thai fried rice. It is the perfect combination, you can also get just plain white rice or brown rice if you choose. 

If I dine in I really like the fried pumpkin as an appetizer. The batter is not too heavy and the pumpkin is really sweet. Imagine a really a big sweet potato fry. Plus it comes with a sweet and sour dipping sauce. 

Also If I dine in, I like to get the Thai iced tea or the fresh coconut juice. Both are very refreshing drinks!

Overall, I am a big fan of Ploy II as it is a local place for me. The food is good and the atmosphere is friendly. Plus all the items range from $8-$12, which is reasonable in my opinion!
author: Allan Y.

description:
Pretty annoyed right now.

Who knows if the food is good, its been almost two hours since I placed my order. 
I guess it's my fault for ordering delivery on a friday night but wow.
I tried to call 6 (six!) times, it rang busy the first couple of times , then it did a loud buzz in my ear (like a fax) then I finally got threw... But then the lady decided to just hang up on me because she couldn't understand me. All I said was "Hi I placed an order about an hour and a half ago and I just want to check and see if it's on it's way or if the driver got lost" yeah..she mumbled something then said "hello" I repeated myself and she hung up on me.

I'm never rude to people. I have a customer service job and I always want to make the customer happy, I was being extremely nice to this person, so I'm kinda annoyed she just hung up on me. 

I just called again and she told me it was on its way....

So hopefully when and if it gets here, it isn't cold and it's as good as everyone says it is. So until then, they are getting one star. Hopefully the food will bring my rating up.

P.S IM SO HUNGRY!
author: Melinda M.

description:
I don't normally write reviews. 
I don't normally write reviews while I am eating the food I'm reviewing...but since two of my dear friends reviews came up on here when I was searching for some dinner to chow down on, I took a chance on Ploy II and was pleasantly, if not extremely surprised and delighted. 

I ordered the fresh spring rolls, tom-kah soup (coconut soup) with chicken, pad see-ew and pad-thai (chicken substituting for prawns). 

Yum.
Yum.
Yum. 

Move over Marnee Thai, move over Phucket on Divis, and definitely move over Thai Place (also on Divis). It's worth the trip for your delivery person from Haight for this food. I can't get enough and my plate doesn't seem to be able to hold the gloriousness that is my dinner from Ploy II. 

I love you tom-kah soup. So much. 

Just do it, take a chance on them. Order. 
Thanks Shan for the jazzy review! xo
author: Betsy K.

description:
We ended up at Ploy II after getting turned away at Abacus nearby, whose kitchen apparently closes at 9:10 p.m.  In this economy, it amazes me how some people will turn away business.

Mobile Yelp to the rescue though, and we ventured over to Ploy II where we were seated and served right away.  The service was very friendly, the food good and very affordable.  We also enjoyed the atmosphere in an upstairs dining room overlooking the street.
author: David C.

description:
I was looking for a place in the neighborhood that delivered Thai, and had a $15 minimum or less. Ploy II is all of those things, but the food was pretty disappointing.

Got the yellow curry with chicken and the corn cakes, neither were that great, but they were edible. I guess I shouldn't be surprised, I've lived in this area for six years and have never eaten here, or been recommended to eat here. 

I thought by ordering in the neighborhood I would have a shorter wait for the food, but as soon as I opened it I wished I had ordered elsewhere and just waited longer. I was so excited for curry, and it just really wasn't that good.
author: Amanda D.

description: I was pleasantly surprised by this place; the mango panang curry and pad thai are delicious and prices seem to be very reasonable. Ambiance is nice and cozy. I had a bird's-eye view of workers at Escape From New York tossing pizza dough from where I was sitting and it was pretty entertaining to watch them while I ate :)
author: Jenny Q.

description:
I think this was one of the first restaurants I went to the Haight, when I first moved to SF in 1999. I remember thinking, cool -- then never hanging out in the neighborhood. It's just a tad too touristy and full of suburban punks.

Service is friendly, the food is good but nothing special. I had the pumpkin curry with chicken.  They do seem pretty flexible with veg options, subbing with tofu.  But it's not worth making a special trip -- there's probably a place in your neighborhood you would hold more dear.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
The smells of Thai cooking waft down the steps as you wander up into this restaurant tucked away off busy Haight street.

The servers are all super friendly and attentive, making sure your experience is everything you want it to be.

We started with the papaya salad and some Singha. The salad was big and yummy. I then got the pad thai and my date the spicy salmon. The pad thai was huge and really good, although a little greasy, but isn't it always? The fish was a little dry but still good.

Overall it was a great experience and I will go back and try more of the menu. For my first time eating Thai food since I've been back from Thailand, it was satisfying and successful!
author: Rachel G.

description:
This is simply the best Thai food I've ever had. In fact, it's the only Thai restaurant I've been to where the food distinguishes itself from the run-of-the-mill. 

Favorite dishes so far:  Dry beef with eggplant, mango curry with shrimp, fried pumpkin appetizer.
author: Todd H.

description:
This place never fails. After living in the haight for 3 years I've taken so many different friends and new roommates and tried many different things on the menu. Results? EVERY dish is consistently delicious. The inside is also really cute, originally meant to be a living space, it has a cozy feel and is perfect for a small group to eat family style or for a casual dinner for 2. 

And they deliver!
author: Vivian Q.

description:
I really really wanted to like this place...super charming building, amazing location, good prices, and solid/normal thai menu. We live right down the street and popped in for a lunch. 

The pad thai was just ok - way too sweet, not enough flavour or fish sauce and was slightly cold 3 stars for the pad thai. 

the free soup was literally water with some mushy carrots - seriously awful. 

the pad se ew was terrible, mushy, stuck together noodles and absolutely flavorless...worst pad se ew i've ever tasted, almost unedible. My wife and i are absolute thai food freaks, love it and this was some of the worst i've ever had. 

If you are looking for an authentic thai meal AVOID, go down the street to Best of Thai Noodle House - food is solid there...how they have 3.5 stars and this place has 4 is beyond me.
author: Ben B.

description:
Very good Thai food! Mango sticky rice not the best
But we had a good duck dish as well as curry. 
I would go back if I was in the area but Thialand Rest.
is the closest for us
author: Chris Y.

description:
There are a ton of Thai restaurants within a 5 block radius in the Haight, so a Thai place has to do something pretty good to stand out. 

I like Ploy because it feels like you're dining in someone's living room. No, really. As in, you can see the kitchen and there's a converted fireplace. Not sure if the original owners of the Victorian imagined cute Asian women walking around in colorful Thai apparel when they first built the house, but hey, all the best laid plans...

Anyway. The waitress literally came up to us ever 3 minutes after we sat down to ask if we were ready. We were too busy looking at the neon-colored signs on the walls (looks like they were written by someone's daughter) to figure out what we wanted to eat, but she stressed us out so much that we ordered quickly, out of pressure.

I guess that's how the best decisions are made. We got curry noodles with chicken, which were a good level of spicy, but not that impressive. I wish there were more veggies in it. 

The Spicy Basil Beef (Pad Ka Prao) stole the show. Seriously good flavors. I loved it.

The prices are okay, the service is okay (aside from being a little pushy), the decor is kitschy. I'd say it ranks below Citrus Club, but is a close second.
author: Hannah L.

description:
I tried Ploy II because  a friend recommended it. I'm glad she did because I would have never taken the plunge otherwise. I like good atmosphere when I dine out so I was originally drawn to the The Citrus Club (down a block or two). 

However, I was pleasantly surprised by Ploy II's reasonable prices and friendly staff. I ordered the pad thai spicy and it came out almost perfect (they could have made it spicier). 

Overall, this is a quaint upstairs authentic thai restaurant with good food and good prices. This is not the place I want to take my friends before a night out on the town but it is perfect for a quiet dinner for two.

They also serve thai hot tea-AMAZING. Sometimes, the little things count in a big way...

I'll be back soon!!
author: Kristin F.

description:
Aside from the fact that when you walk in, it is truly the San Franciscan experience you expect, the food itself was delicious.

It looks like you're walking into a Victorian house, and you're sitting at somebody else's dining room. Cozy, friendly, great food, cheap wine bottles.

I would definitely come back.
author: Roxy G.

description: Lots of Thai restaurants in SF; nope, haven't been to them all, so there is the possibility there is better.  But, at this point, of the approx. 10 that I've tried, this is my favorite.  Consistently good.   Everything.  And nice people.  All my faves -- chicken satay, pad thai, tom kha kai and yellow curry chicken, all excellent!  I just wish they served my very favorite Thai curry dish, Mussamun, but you only get that at certain places as it's a regional dish.  If you don't live in the Haight, it's definitely worth the trip, and great homey ambience.
author: Merrick W.

description: It's among the best Thai places in the West side of SF. The restaurant itself reminded me of someone's house. The options were plentiful and all sounded appetizing. Highlights were the green curry with pork and the broiled salmon with spicy sauce. The curry was perfectly spiced, delicious, and there was a plenty. The salmon was cooked well, and the sauce, a reduction, was awesome. Overall, it was cozy, comfortable, authentic, and allowed for a good dining experience. Definitely recommend for a casual date night or for friends!
author: Richard R.

description:
Stopped in here on a very wintry summer day. We were treated to cozy second floor window seats overlooking one of the most colorful neighborhoods in America. Fifty years later, there are still blue-haired nymphettes in torn fishnet stockings roaming Haight St., and hyper-tattooed teenagers wailing their hearts out on beater guitars, hoping to catch the occasional TV camera rolling by. 

In the quiet of the upstairs Victorian, we inhaled plump chicken satay dunked in a thick, sweet peanut sauce, and a mound of savory pad thai. If I lived here, I'd be home now. Truly as nostalgic inside as out, this meal left us feeling all warm and snuggly inside, bookending a great day as the late afternoon fog blanketed the city.

Thanks for the great food memory and I'll be back when I'm in the area again, unless of course you expand your delivery area to Phoenix.
author: Eireen C.

description:
Sorry Ploy II, you're getting demoted. 

Too many times have I waited twenty minutes to finally get the check taken care of and I'm no longer impressed with the pad thai. 

Don't get me wrong, it is tasty, but I swear there's more bean sprouts than noodles!
author: Murphy O.

description: Wow this place was amazing! I don't know what everyone is talking about with the bad service, if you're a jerk, you're going to get treated like one. Our servers were very nice and efficient. We had the mango panang curry and it was amazing. And shared the pad Thai which was also delicious. The decor is really cute and different. Affordable prices too!
author: Brooklynn M.

description:
I kept having random people tell me that I had to eat here, so last night I took a couple of friends in town upstairs about 20 minutes before the place closed. The friendly staff did not even make a comment about the time, seated us and served us with a smile and no rush. The food was very good, though 3 of us got Panang dishes, the portions were nice and the price was great. Plus, we got a window table and spent the meal looking out at the people parade in front of the Red Vic movie theater.

Now that I've been here, I'm completely sold and will both recommend and return.

Oh, and I gave it $$ instead of $ because you will probably want a drink or something, but if you just get an entree and water you can eat for under $10.
author: Greg G.

description:
I never thought of myself as a fan of Thai food but yet here I am reviewing three of them. Go fig. 

This is a place you take someone to show how cool you are. And it really is a cool space: an old Victorian apartment with the best seats by the window overlooking Haight street. I wouldn't bring more then four people with me as the space is small but it is perfect for a couple. 

The food is really good. I order the pepper and garlic shrimp. My friends have never been disappointed with their food or the service. The waitresses wear traditional Thai outfit with sneakers which I find cute, They are however entirely too thin.
author: lily l.

description:
Verdict:  delicious food, friendly service, left very satisfied and ate absolutely everything on each and every plate (yeah, def not a girl that eats a piece of lettuce and a breathmint for lunch).  

Order for three:  Tom Kha soup, Roast Duck Curry, Cashew Nut Chicken, and Garlic Pepper Prawns.  For dessert, splurged on fried bananas with mango and coconut ice cream (nom, nom, nom).  Everything was excellent.  Bonus point for having brown rice.

Service:  very friendly, food came out fast, the server refilled our water 3-4 times, and brought everything we asked for in a timely manner.

The only thing that took away from experience was the heat.  As there is no AC in the restaurant, the high summer temps are hard to take, especially as you're eating spicy food.  However, the weather is not the restaurant's fault, surely it's very pleasant 95% of the time, I should take a point away from someone upstairs ;-)  The server did open a window per my request and placed a small fan on a table behind us.  While I may not be back during a hot summer day, I will definitely make this place my go-to Thai restaurant.
author: Marina S.

description:
So......

Their delivery sucks? --- Gotcha

Don't go when it's really, really busy? --- Gotcha

OK....

With those two out of the way:

This is the BEST Thai food I've had in the city thus far. My father's Thai & I've eaten a lot of Thai food in my life... and I can honestly say that after trying 10+ restaurants in SF this one is THE best.

(I'm ALWAYS disappointed in other place's portion sizes, ingredients, prices, TASTE, etc).

---------------------------------------------

My experience (lunch on a weekday) was perfect!

- Beautiful upstairs restaurant: Quaint, lovely, homey, and CLEAN!

- Friendly service (I had no problems here whatsoever)

- Very fair prices (can't complain here either.. Even the dinner prices aren't as bad as they could be)

- EXTRAORDINARY *THAI CUISINE* !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

---------------------------------------------

....... Who you gonna trust? Someone with no profile pic & under 15 reviews or an Elite member with nearly hundreds of reviews who's half Thai & endlessly raving about THIS restaurant?!?!?!  :sigh:

Another one of the easiest 5 Stars I've ever had to give out.

CHECK. Them. Out. NOW!

(And thank me later)

^ . ^

P.S. The "$$" rating of this place's prices isn't right. It should be just one "$." Look at their menu to see what I mean.
author: Kai S.

description:
Having a meal at Ploy II is like taking an 18-hour plane ride to Thailand to visit your grandmother's kitchen - it's that mind-blowing that it can zap you to Thailand w/o having to pay the $900 airline ticket.  

We usually order our staple thai food - Tom Kha seafood, spring rolls, panang curry, spicy tofu and pad see-ew.  We do stray from time to time and venture into the other items on the menu - and they always deliver - the food is pact with awesome flavors and comes in generous portion enough for family-style dining.

To top off this mind-blowing dining experience - the staff and owner - Soon Yee treats us like family  - so It really feels like thai-style comfort food made in grandma's kitchen.
author: Michelle B.

description:
Thom Ka Ghai was a disappointment. The base of the soup was broken like it had been reheated a few too many times. The green curry was okay; nothing amazing and barely any meat. The rice was mushy. My friend had Phad Thai and it was great despite the shortage of noodles and overabundance of bean sprouts to cover the plate.
Thai iced tea was just okay and the cucumber salad barely had cucumbers in it. The place is not the cleanest. Years of dust build-up on the light fixtures, etc.
The prices are right for what you get- it's cheap. On a positive note, the staff is super attentive and genuinely friendly. 
If you're in the area and don't want to waste your time looking for a place with better food, then settle.
author: Erin B.

description:
I wish I could review Ploy II's food. I really do.

Tonight my roommate and I placed a takeout order at 8:20pm. We live on Ashbury... 4 blocks away. We ordered, were stoked because they took credit card (Best of Thai doesn't), and were told the food would be here in 15 minutes. Sweet.

Then 9:00 hit. We called back. Where's our food? Oh... It just finished cooking.... It'll be here in 5 minutes? Okay.

9:20. It's been an hour. We call back again. Oh the food is finally done? But the delivery guy wasn't around? 

No apology whatsoever. No offer of a discount. We cancelled the order and walked to Best of Thai. I paid for the stupid ATM next door since I needed cash. From the time we ordered to the time we walked out the door, B.O.T. took 4 minutes and 17 seconds to get us our food. I timed it to prove a point.

I will never order from Ploy II again. It could be the best food in San Francisco, it's not worth it.
author: jared c.

description: It's not the most outstanding Thai place I've been to but it's a go-to. I love that it's like sitting in someone's house, and it's quiet and intimate. Occasionaly, it seems like there's someone serving who has never done it before, but everyone is friendly. Super cheap and basic wine list, and the bill didn't hurt my wallet. What's not to like?
author: Mi M.

description:
Worst delivery experience EVER! 

I've eaten in their restaurant many times and always enjoyed my meals. I had never tried their delivery until this evening and will NEVER - EVER - EVER - NEVER give these people my business again.

Strike 1 : Was told over the phone that delivery would arrive in 45 minutes. A hungry hour and fifteen minutes later... it finally did

Strike 2:  After paying and tipping the driver I went inside to eat. I opened the boxes and realized  the bag I was given was NOT my order. It was completely wrong and obviously some other persons order. I called to inform them and ask for my correct order to be brought.

Strike 3: Second round of delivery took 30 more  hungry minutes to arrive. The food was totally cold and get this... the order was incomplete! Still wrong.

You're out: When I called to inform them again of the missing items and request a refund, they wouldn't give me a refund because I paid with my credit card. So another 30 minutes later after finishing my cold meal, the door bell rings and I open the door to see their driver literally running back to his car while he has left the bag of delivered goods tied to the door handle. And get this... the "corrected" order was still wrong even after 3 attempts. 

This place is dead to me
author: deborah g.

description:
Usually I'm weary of Asian places where I'm the only Asian in sight and the entire menu's in English, but for Ploy II, I suspended my skepticism in favor of some blind faith in San Franciscans' discerning palates. 

Go for:
-the "welcome to Grandma's house" vibe, and dammnnn Grams can COOK!
-the specials that are written on multiple walls, so you can literally see them wherever you sit. **BONUS: I didn't spot a single spelling error.
-the friendly service

Get: 
-Roasted Duck Curry--thank you Ploy II for not skimping on the duck
-Dry Curry Beef w/ Eggplant--not as dry as I imagined, but SO TASTY

Skip:
-Thai iced tea--on the smallish side and tastes just like everyone else's
-fried shrimp thingies with dipping sauce-- sound fancy on the appetizer menu, but this is just firecracker shrimp under a different name, y'all. snooze.

You will score major "hole in the wall" points for taking friends here!
author: Cindy Q.

description: OK, the past few times, the service has been much better.  Im gonna move it up a star
author: Claudia M.

description: Best authentic Thai food I've ever had. It was chill.
author: Danielle C.

description:
Meh. Nothing terrible, nothing special. 

We had the spring rolls which were generic but tasty enough, the crispy tofu with peanut sauce (peanut sauce needed way more spice), and the red curry with veggies & tofu.

The portions were quite generous for the price. A bottle of drinkable Pinot Grigio was $18 & the service was perfect (they left us alone as we caught up on the last ten years).
author: Jenn W.

description:
the place itself is very secluded so you'd have to see the number of the address because there was no sign of the restaurant at all before we came up. after we found the door, i thought it was someone's house or something. so we have to pass the stairs first, it was red old carpeted stairs and it's a small vintage looking thai restaurant upstairs. they can use it as an apartment  but instead it's a restaurant.
I tried the yellow curry vegetable with brown rice as my main course. i also tried the vegetarian pastry puff as my appetizer, it's like samosa but bigger filled with vegetable, taste great. the yellow curry also taste good and thai authentic. 
service is attentive & unpretentious.
It is definitely a nice place to visit again in the future.
author: Ms C.

description:
After reading all the reviews, they sounded pretty great!

So the girlfriend and I pick up the phone at 8pm on a nice and lazy Sunday evening and place an order for delivery. We only live a few blocks away, and it was cold and foggy, so hey, delivery please! "It will be there within an hour!" said the person on the phone. 

Fantastic. Prepare taste buds for awesome.

An hour goes by. This is kind of strange.

An hour and a half goes by. Okay, now we're just being nice and we're pretty damn hungry to be this nice. So we call them up to find out where it is. "Oh, sorry! It will be there in 20 minutes."

Grrrr.

20 minutes turns into another 30. So we call them again and say that it's been 2 hours since we originally placed our order. The man on the phone was very apologetic and said they just started cooking it.

Ugh!

So we had to unfortunately cancel our order, since anyone who had wanted to eat had long ago starved to death. :-(

Maybe we'll try this place again sometime. Just make sure to always have emergency rations.
author: Dave S.

description:
I wasn't a big fan of Thai food until I tried Ploy. It's in my neighborhood, I gave it a try, and I'm a convert. The service is odd, (and in this case odd isn't a euphemism for bad) but friendly, and the food is consistently fab whether I eat in or have it delivered. 

The tofu prih-king, spicy fish, imperial rolls, mango panang curry, roasted duck curry--wait, this is crazy--let's just say I've never, in 13 years, had anything that hasn't been worth having again. And again. Oh yeah, and don't forget to order the roti for dessert!
author: Elle C.

description:
Still a bit sweeter than I prefer my Thai food, but nonetheless delicious. Had a beef and eggplant dish, which sounded like an odd combination, but worked quite well.

As others have noted, the "matron" is a little annoying. After picking up my takeout, I noticed I had no utensils. Upon going back up stairs to ask for a fork and knife, she said, "No knife, fork". I couldn't tell if she was telling me they didn't have any knives, or that I couldn't have one.

Nonetheless, the phrase "you feel like you're eating in someone's house" gets thrown around way too often these days, but it truly is the case here, as it literally is a converted old Victorian.
author: Mark A.

description:
I'm giving Ploy II five stars because they're only one of two or three good places to eat in Upper Haight. Alembic is good but it's expensive. Magnolia is overrated. Citrus Club...meh. Cha Cha Cha is just OK. Best of Thai....bleh. If I had to choose one place in Upper Haight then it's here. It's cozy and the food is actually good. Thai food in SF is sort of a dime a dozen since they're everywhere but I'd say Ploy II is one of the best in the city.

....plus they have cute servers.
author: David C.

description:
This is a really great place!! The food is SO GOOD, its cute that its in a used to be a house, sometimes the staff can be not so friendly, but you can look past that on how awesome the food is. My favorite is the fried pumpkin, YUM!!  

I have gone on a weekend night and the place was packed and I have gone on a week night, and the place was kind of dead.
author: T C.

description:
One of my favorite delivery places!
I've had delivery from here at least a dozen time..probably more
In fact I just ordered from them for dinner tonight!

I love Tom Kha and theirs is excellent (though not as good as The Citrus Club *drool*).
They have a huge vegetarian and seafood selection and they will even deliver the Thai Iced Tea and the Fried Banana with Ice Cream. Rad.

Calling in your order can be a pain sometimes, but eventually you get whet you need ;-)
author: Linz H.

description: I have never sat down and ate in the restaurant, but have taken out food a number of times.  The food comes fast, hot, and always great.  The red curry, pad thai and ka pra are delicious!  The shrimp dishes comes with just 3 shrimp which is disappointing, but it is still good.  Drunken noodles are amazing!
author: Rita W.

description: My favorite restaurant on Height! I always get the curry chicken. Its a bunch of noodles and vegatables and chicken in a coconut curry soup. Its soo good and the place is really reasonable, the prices are even cheaper during lunch. I always look forward to eating here. I don't think it is the best place for big groups, I think its better for just a couple people. The place is pretty small. Check it out! I think their food is a lot better then Citrus Club, Citrus Club does have better atmosphere though.
author: Lisa W.

description:
It's nothing to write home about, but I did inhale a lot of my yellow curry so it wasn't that bad.

The restaurant is upstairs, crowded and bustling with little ladies in traditional garb.  Sadia and I spilt the veggie egg rolls and the taro root appetizer.  Greasy, fried, and good when you're starving.

The pad see ew was decent and the tofu yellow curry didn't have a whole ton of tofu in it, but was ok.  I'd go back again if Siam Lotus wasn't open.
author: Jen I.

description:
Ploy II is right around the corner from my place so its my first stop for thai food when the mood strikes me... Which is far more often then I care to admit, oh well. 
Pretty traditional thai, same stuff you could get anywhere in Sf, that being said, I think they do it the best very true, or at least the way my step mom from thai land did it... just not as spicy thank god. 
So to start with my favorite Spicy Basil with pork, yes hell yes it is so delicious. Not overly sauced, some how through the power of thai magic every-time it is cooked perfectly. the Panang Curry with chicken, IS BOMB, maybe heavy on the peanut for others but thats how i like it. Pad See Ew with beef, not at all greasy like would get at other places. Pan fried to perfection again not too much sauce perfect. 
To me the Satay, or the pad thai things like that have a pretty universal standard, i just prefer the way they do it, and for the price it puts them up there for me. I'll see you soon Ploy II, i'll see you soon.
author: Sean MC E.

description:
Same problem as Dave S.  I cannot comment on the food, but don't bother trying to get a delivery from Ploy II.  We called at around 8pm with a $50+ order and had an awful experience.

1) I had to call several times to order because I kept calling and being put on hold only to be totally forgotten.  While it didn't feel like a big deal at first, it got kinda ridiculous when I was mid-order and asking her what the meat options were for one of the dishes...

2) She said that it would arrive in 50-55 minutes, and nothing came after 75 minutes.  I was under the impression that they were on schedule since she called me to ask if I wanted rice at minute 40.

3) I call at around minute 75, and find that they are "just finishing up" and it will take another 15-20 minutes to get the dishes out.  Having worked in a restaurant before, I know this means that they have just started with my order in the kitchen.

I found this to be a bit ridiculous, so I just canceled our order - they weren't even apologetic and just hung up on me.  We called Thai Noodle House for a pickup instead - 5 dishes ready in 10 minutes...now that's more like it!
author: Fontane L.

description: Panang curry done right. I've had it in Thailand, and this is the closest to that experience I've come to in 8 years. It's RIGHT ON! The service was swift and pleasant, they took care of us, and the price is perfect. The deep fried pumpkin was interesting, but there was too much of it! Amazing sauce to go along with that dish too. Considering the location, tourist central and all, it was fast and cheap and delicious. Will return...
author: Mike L.

description:
I've spent over a year in Thailand, and I feel like I have a pretty good sense of what it should taste like.

Every visit to Ploy II has been a good meal. The food authentic tasting and service is friendly. These aren't the prices you'd pay in Thailand of course, but the taste is comparable.

I like the weird second floor house atmosphere of the restaurant personally, though I agree with others who mention that it can be cramped.

I'm a fan of their coconut juice, and I think they make it there. It has nice slices of coconut meat in it. Otherwise, you can get a whole young coconut to sip from.
author: Nik D.

description:
A couple  things that everyone needs to try from here: fried pumpkin and the panang mango with prawns. Both are to die for! The panang is my favorite dish from here by far...I wish I had some in a bowl with me right now!

Besides those two delicious dishes, this place is pretty awesome. I've enjoyed everything that I have eaten from here, and the service is good.
 
I'd much rather enjoy my food at the restaurant as well because it's so homey and nicely decorated! Its a very comfortable environment, and this would be my first recommendation to anyone who wants to hit up a lovely Thai restaurant in the city.
author: Lisa B.

description:
I like Thai food and this is one restaurant I return to. One thing that always trips me out is that you have to walk upstairs to get to the restaurant. There aren't too many places to get food on the upper level.  

I love the fresh ingredients and the home cooked feel to the food. There is a great variety offered. I order the spicy noodles and Thai fried rice.  The Pad Thai is delectable. 

I just have to time my excursion here as parking can get nuts.
author: Infodiva B.

description: Fabulous Tom Ka Kai Soup! After moving to the haight, the one place everyone kept telling me to go was Ploy II.  If it hadn't been for the recommendation i probably wouldn't have gone there since it was upstairs (out of sight out of mind).  We were pleasantly surprised, warm atmosphere, great view of haight street (near the window) and the food was fantastic.  I'm kind of a Thai snob and this place delivers.  Plus I'm vegetarian so there are lots of veggie options.  Highly recommend.
author: Dj S.

description:
Mmmm, crystal noodles.  My current favorite Thai place.

3 stars instead of 4 because of the fact that I called yesterday to place an order, which commenced OK and then partway through the gal on the phone was all, "oh, we're not open today.  Call Friday."  Um, OK?

Delicious, if a bit confusing.
author: Polly Enmity P.

description:
The food was actually really good for the price, and this review is centered around the service.

My friend and I had to wait for over 30 minutes to get our food because a "cook forgot our order." This in itself would have been okay except that we were not notified at all. I had to ask the waiter what was taking so long (people that got in later than us had already gotten their food).

I found gum in my napkin. 

My spoon was also stained and had bits of food on it. It was clearly dirty.

Finally, the waiter really wasn't very attentive, and only filled our water glasses right before we left. 

Again, I want to stress: I found GUM in my napkin.

This was one of the very few times that I did not give a tip at a restaurant. My friend called me an asshole for not leaving a couple bucks, but I subscribe to the idea that tips are given for service. 

If you want to get their thai food, just order take-out.
author: Jay Z.

description:
Consistently great thai food and great, fast service, nice balance of innovative dishes and classics.  The upstairs location is *super* charming.

Best to call ahead if you have a group over 4 and don't bother for groups over 6-8-- they only have one large table.
author: adam s.

description:
Ploy II is one of those places whose names I know well but whose locations I could never really nail down.  It's in the Haight, right?  Or maybe it's in the Inner Sunset?  On 16th Street?  No, on 8th Avenue.  No, wait, that's Thai Time.

Anyway, when I finally came here for the first time, it was a total trip.  First because I thought it was way on the other end of the Upper Haight.  It's actually near Citrus Club, which is strange because I always used to walk right by Citrus Club and wonder what the other Thai place was that people said was nearby.  Well, duh, it's Ploy II.

I love the fact that this place used to be someone's flat.  I have no idea how long it's been since the last residents moved out, but I like the fact that it looks 79 percent identical to where I live.  Except for the slapped-on wood paneling.  And the poorly made and lettered signs.  And the smells.  And the delicious food cooking in the kitchen.

The food is really good.  The service is also good.  I wish they had figured out a way to allow people to sit in every single little room, but if wishes were fishes, the seas would be full.  Or something like that.

UPDATE:  1/7/11
=============

I'm docking Ploy II a star because it's completely wheelchair inaccessible.
author: John S.

description: The duck salad here is fabulous. Awesome seating arrangements too, the restaurant is built on the second floor of an old Edwardian. Great food and not a bad wine list.
author: Juan P.

description: Thai food...I don't really have much more to say.  I got the Phrik Khing with chicken and my boyfriend had the Pad See Mow with Pork.  They were both average.  We also got the fried Won Tons, which had an interesting green spinach-like veggie inside.  With every bite I had wished there was cream cheese as well.  I'd try it again if I was starving and in the area but it didn't wow me.  The beer/wine prices were pretty great though - $2.50 beers and $4 wine.
author: Jennifer T.

description: This was the worst delivery I have EVER experienced. We order three entrees because of the good reviews, only to be astronomically disapointed. An hour and a half after ordering- they told us 45 min max for delivery.... we finally get our food. Only to find that it is the WRONG order. We called the restaurant and two hours later were given our order. I called the restaurant to discuss this unfortunate experience and the women said sorry can you just "let it go..." and said she would call back and never did. I will never order from here again the food wasn't even good it was gross, cold, and half-opened. Literally like food out of a dumpster.
author: Grace B.

description:
This place gives off a tourist trap vibe so I have avoided it for much of my 20 years in SF, but this time I was in a hurry. Tourist traps don't have to worry about quality because they are located in places that have an endless supply of victims who leave SF shortly thereafter. Thankfully we have Yelp to set things straight.

This is bland food for people who don't know what good Thai is supposed to taste like. The Tom Yum tasted like boullian cubes, the spicy basil pork dish I ordered was very bland. The only thing that I ordered that was passable was the Pad Thai.

If you don't have much experience with thai food and are easily pleased by sweet, bland dishes, then maybe you will like it here. If you have ever had decent Thai in the past, avoid.
author: C S.

description: I love this place for multiple reasons, but the item that keeps me coming back for more is the MANGO PANANG CURRY. You can get it veg. or with meat or seafood and it's all sorts of amazing. I live near this spot and have to stop myself from ordering this item several times a week. The payaya salad is amazing as well and I love the spot itself. It's located upstairs, and it's literally a house turned into a Thai restaurant. I wish I could come home to amazing food being served from their converted kitchen, but alas, I cannot. Bring people who like good food and a funky ambiance. The staff are friendly and the hand-written specials on the wall are also pretty tasty as well.
author: Dani B.

description:
I came here for my birthday with a party of 21 (very organized) students, and we had great service. We were impressed with the menu and the reasonable prices for Height Street. Don't let the outward appearance scare you away. Ploy II is inside of a beautiful Victorian house.

WARNING: If you have a large party like me, make a reservation and be organized throughout the ordering process. The employees were a bit intimidated until they realized that we are incredibly organized. We share a common profession which plans events as a stereotype :).
author: Tony G.

description:
9pm on a Friday night there was a 20 minute wait.  That is about perfect for me... any less and I am suspicious of their quality, any more and I'm ready to grab a burrito elsewhere and scrap a pleasant dinner experience.

If I somehow get very wealthy in the next few years, I am going to steal all the waitresses and install them as my personal assistants.  They were all cute and rushed around carrying steaming plates of tasty like their lives depended upon it.

We ordered 4 dishes, all of which arrived alongside our wine within 10 minutes of ordering.  It was kinda amazing actually: I felt like we were a nest of hungry birds serviced by 4 or 5 parents... dressed in traditional Thai garb.

The food was amazing: soup was great, pad see ew was probably the best I'd ever had, beef salad was super flavorful, as was the papaya salad.

they actually forgot to bring dish #5, which was actually a blessing in disguise because by that time we were all stuffed and didn't need an extra serving of gluttony.

Prices were great, food was awesome, waitresses were amusing.  can't go wrong.  except, don't get the most expensive ($18) bottle of wine... it tastes like watered down grape juice.
author: Mari C.

description:
Mango Panang Curry. done.

It is that good.  The fried pumpkin is a great appetizer.  We also had a very standard spicy eggplant dish.  Everything was delicious.  The peanut sauce on the praram was excellent.  

I wish it were a larger restaurant, but It feels cozy. If you can sit near the window the people watching is always fun.
author: David C.

description:
REALLY yummy thai food. We had papaya salad, vegetable silver noodles, red chicken curry and pad thai. All dishes were super yummy! I have this habit now of always ordering pad thai each time i go to a thai restaurant because I want to find the perfect one. i think the best one i've had so far is at Osha. However, today's is actually comparable. 
The vegetable silver noodles (vermicelli noodles) were really yummy as well. Perfect for vegetarians! 
The restaurant is like inside an old victorian. When you enter the restaurant, you have to go upstairs. The layout is like a regular house, except they've turned it into a restaurant. It's super cute. 
I highly recommend that you try it out!
author: Sharon G.

description:
Oh no! 

Ploy II badly disappointed last night. Very uneven, and a couple of dishes we left untouched. 

Repeated requests for chili finally brought a pre-fab dispenser of pizza parlor red flakes and Vietnamese-style red sauce but no Thai chili in vinegar which is absolutely required for duck noodle soup.

And since when does Tom Yum Gai have brown broccoli in it? Pretty nasty.

Both soups arrived without any chili whatsoever in it. Pull that just once in Bangkok you'd have a street riot on your hands. Maybe its necessary now to demand chili when ordering. Avoid the soups. Or better still, go elsewhere.

Not one to complain about slow service, food made to order takes time but our five main dishes arrived over 15-20 minutes. Eating in front of hungry friends suuucks.

Unfortunate too were the crotch-reeking teen panhandlers sprawled on the waiting bench eating from to-go containers with their bare, grime knuckled hands.  Can't say we'll give Ploy II another chance, there's too many consistently better options to choose from. What a shame, it used to be good.
author: J D.

description:
Ploy II is the shit, plain and simple.  Even though they're four blocks from my house, I usually get delivery- and that's not just because I'm a lazy ass.  I've dined in the restaurant several times and the story is always the same: if you go during peak hours, it could take at least a half hour to get seated, and the service is incredible slow.  An okay option if you get there no later than 6:30 and don't have to be anywhere for a while.

My favorite dishes are the Imperial Egg Rolls (fried, of course), the Pad Thai (widely regarded as the best EVER), and the Panang Curry.  I've tried several other dishes but these are my mainstays.  Basically anything you order is going to be grubalicious.
author: Ellen L.

description:
Friends brought me here while visiting S.F.  

The combination of great company, delicious food, reasonable prices, a warm and friendly atmosphere made it a happy experience for me. 

Felt like I was home, in someone else's house, it's a a converted old Victorian. Never would have noticed the restaurant if I wasn't steered in the doorway, very quaint.
author: don f.

description: There are a bunch of Thai places that I can never remember the name of until I walk past. So, finally took a photo to remember that one where you have to walk upstairs, next to the cheap lingerie and thigh-high place. It's Ploy II. (Wonder where Ploy I is?)  I've had several good things here. The Green Curry is consistent, the sticky rice with mango for dessert is fantastic and the specials can be interesting. I once had the pumpkin yellow curry, which was nice, but I prefer more tofu, less pumpkin. The spices are just right here. Service can be slow, but it feels like homemade food, so it's worth the wait. Take-out gets you food fast enough to order and wait for it.
author: Kat T.

description: Mediocre service, rude supervisor, pad thai and tom yum smelled rancid and the noodles were chewy. Wouldn't recommend. A lot of hipsters come here though, if you're into that.
author: Erin C.

description:
I am going to have to give them 2 stars. Why you ask?  Well, there food is good and their prices are very reasonable and I have not had a bad delivery experience with them yet however, they violated my biggest dining pet peeve....they rushed us out of our table very quickly.  

It was obvious that we were to get in, eat and get out fast! The matron of the restaurant kept coming over and saying "thanks for coming, bye bye".  It was horrible, I do not like being rushed out of restaurants especially when you are there with friends and enjoying good conversation.  I would expect to be rushed in and out of place at McDonalds or TGIF's but not at your local Thai restaurant, it is just sad! Let people stay and enjoy, they will end coming back for more and spending more money!
author: Jasmine K.

description:
My wife and I used to go here when we lived in the area and returned last night for our first date night in a very long time (kids). It was even better than we remembered! 

The fresh spring rolls were awesome. The green pumpkin curry is the type of food I would kill for and the sizzling spicy tofu plate was unbelievable. It was the best curry I have had since we went to Thailand. Oh, and the fried banana with coconut ice cream for dessert wasn't too bad either.
author: Wade B.

description: Some of the best Thai food in the city - excellent flavors and haven't ordered any item that I've regretted. Pepper chicken/beef and drunken noodles are solid.
author: N. M.

description:
I've been to thailand now for 5 times, and this food really brings me back there. food is amazing, the appearance of the stuff very professional, and i just love the feeling of sitting in someone's living room, so cozy.
My favorites are - actually the whole menu! Just try everything you won't be disappointed....
author: Kika H.

description:
I can't really vouch for the food since all I ordered was the vegetable pad thai and thai iced tea. The restaurant is really nice and the waitstaff is friendly. I also like that the windows are HUGE, so it's lit very well in the daytime. Some of the other menu items looked good as well, and it looked like they had quite a few vegetarian options.

The best part is the price. If you come during lunch, there are lunch specials and from what I remember, the lunch dishes were at least 2 dollars less than a la carte. I'd definitely return just to try some of the other dishes.
author: Conrad C.

description: I love the authentic decor in this place, even though I've never actually sat down and eaten there, every time I go to pick up my togo order I always notice how adorable the interior is.  The food is delicious and the service has been great.  My favorite dishes are the pumpkin curry and pineapple fried rice.  This place is a must if you like Thai food!
author: Megan M.

description:
I have been coming to this place for years and its still holding its top marks!  I actually believe that this place developed my love for Thai food!

The food is very good, the portions are generous and the prices are very reasonable, in fact, I dont think they have raised their prices much over the years.

I like that this restaurant is located in what used to be someone's house.  You feel so welcome going up the stairs, like you are coming to a friend's place for dinner.  All the servers are dressed in traditional Thai garments, are really nice, attentive and pretty. 

I like to sit at the window table and watch Haight street traffic go by.  Ploy II, you never let me down!
author: Anya T.

description:
I love ploy II. I live right across the street, which is why we discovered it. It's upstairs and is an old Victorian flat converted into a restaurant. How much more charming can it be? 

Their prices are reasonable (about $7 for pad thai and $8-$10 for curries). Their spicy pumpkin curry is outstanding. One order of curry and rice with an appetizer is plenty for 2 people.  I recommend the sweet and spicy tofu appetizer. The service is also good. The waitresses usually wear Thai style dresses and are very attentive.

I think it is way better than Siam Lotus, which is right across the street. If you are in upper Haight and want Thai food, definitely pick Ploy II.
author: Vickie D.

description:
Last 3 times we've ordered from here, we've been gravely disappointed.  Well, 3 strikes and they're now out of our rotation.  The straw that broke the camel's back?  They refused to make a simple substitution that would have SAVED them time!  Our request?  Could we have the tofu "unfried" in our pad thai.  Would have saved them time (and $), but no can do.  We were told they make NO substitutions.  That's okay, since that's their choice.  And we have a choice, too.  There's plenty of other places for us to take our business that WILL skip the step of frying our tofu upon request.

Oh, and by the way, this is my very first one-star rating.  I tend to grade on the high end of the curve.  But this one-star rating feels well-deserved in my book, based on three consecutive bad experiences.
author: Susan L.

description: Always hits the spot. Delicious and easy. Big plus for their delivery. With so many Thai choices in SF. Ploy II is one of the best in the neighborhood and for a few other near by neighborhoods too.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
Worst.  Thai delivery.  Experience.  Ever.

Called at about 8pm to order, and was told it would take about 45 minutes.  9:15pm rolls around, no info, so I call back.  They say the food is ready, but the delivery driver is out.  9:50pm rolls around, I call back, the food is finally on its way over.  10:05pm, finally receive food.

So after that terrible experience, I thought at least the food would be good, given the reviews.  Well, it was somewhat cold, due to the long wait.  It also lacked flavor compared to other Thai places I have ordered from.  Will probably never try to order from here again.
author: Amit M.

description:
From now on, I'm only eating at restaurants that occupy the second floor of a converted Victorian (with floor plan and fireplace still intact) overlooking a bustling hipster street scene.  Period.

I'd love to end the review there, but that wouldn't do justice to the food.  Pad Kee Mow and Thai Ice Tea were normal, but things got more interesting and delicious from there: deep-fried pumpkin (take some home and eat it hot over vanilla ice cream), cashew nut tofu (served on a sizzling, incredibly oily skillet--you could make a great Thai fajita if they only had tortillas), and the piece de resistance: prawn panang with mango (or panango, as it will henceforth be called).  Consider it Exhibit A on how to successfully--nay, masterfully--use fruit in a savory dinner dish (and now that my fridge is bursting with Capay Farms deliveries, that's a skill I desperately need to learn).  Yes, the long search for the one Thai restaurant to rule them all is over, and Ploy II is it.  Period.

(For real this time.)
author: Wes M.

description:
I don't know where Ploy I is, and I don't care. 

When I first moved to California, I'd never had Thai food. In fact, I'd never even heard of Thai food. Sure, I knew there was "Thailand," and, durh, of course I understood they ate food there, but, to me, it may as well have been food from Swaziland. I just had no idea that this was a culinary experience that the great United States of America offered, much less a whole sub-category you could find on Yelp. Of course, back when I moved to California, the "Internet" was just barely getting off the ground, so there wasn't even a Yelp yet. 

I tried Thai a few times in Oakland and I was tremendously underwhelmed. The lemon grass flavor was entirely new to me and I just felt like I was eating something flavored in Palmolive. 

After a few attempts at Thai, I gave up and actively avoided going out with friends if they wanted Thai.

Skip forward a few years, and one night I'm on a date and the fella brings me to Ploy II. HOLY COW!!!!!!!! This was a revelation for my taste buds! While the date didn't work out, the food has continued to be a lasting relationship!

The Mieng Kum was amazing, as was the Spicy Tofu. That night, I also tasted Tom Ka (delicious!) and the Vegetable Praram. 

Since my first meal at Ploy II, I've become a Thai food convert and eaten at many other restaurants. For me, however, Ploy II will always be the epitome of what good Thai is all about. 

***This is NOT a wheelchair accessible location. It is on the second floor of a building and the staircase is somewhat narrow (like a normal staircase in a house). Also, the bathroom is quite small, so if you're really big, you might want to skip coming here if you think you'll need the bathroom. 

That's why I did -1 star - not wheelchair accessible and yucky bathroom
author: Hannah Q.

description:
When I was looking for places to live in San Francisco, I had dinner at Ploy II with a potential roommate.  That meal narrowed down my search to "walking distance of Ploy II's deliciousness."

The food is mind bogglingly delicious.  Super fragrant, so spicy it'll clear out your sinuses.  The fresh spring rolls are so good that the restaurant frequently runs out before the dinner rush (it's happened about 60% of the times I go there).  The panang is fantastic, and the pumpkin in the pumpkin curry is so tender and flavorful.  I love that they don't skimp on the veggies either.

My favorite guilty pleasure here is the spicy tofu; deep fried, orange, chili and basil basted goodness.
author: Sarah M.

description:
Ploy II --or Upstairs Thai as it's more commonly known-- is a great place to know about.

I walked by so many times over the years, dodging drug dealers and the other Haight St. riff raff, but one day I decided to check it out.

This place is great. Thai Living Room would also be a good name for it.

Good spot for lunch, if you're in the 'hood and you're over El Belazo and Citrus Club.
author: Jason R.

description:
Ploy II has some of the better cheap Thai food in the city.  The atmosphere is a bit off, giving the feel of dining in someone's living room, rather than a restaurant, but it can be a nice change of scenery.

The food is really well prepared, with the exception of the Tom Kha which lacks flavor and tends to separate like curdled milk.  The deep fried pumpkin and spring rolls are always great, the noodles and curries are perennial crowd pleasers, and the pineapple fried rice is a really unique combination of rice, scallions, raisins, shrimp, pineapple, curry and pork floss (picture what you might find in the lint trap after putting shredded jerky in the clothes drier for an hour).

The service is always gracious and efficient and the price is right.  There aren't many bad things to say about Ploy II.
author: Quinn S.

description:
Hm...where to eat. 

Alembic? Too pricey for a last minute I'm-too-lazy-to-go-home-and-cook dinner.

Cha Cha Cha? Too long a wait for sangria (the only good thing there)

The Citrus Club? 40 minutes for 5 people...ugh.

Then came Ploy II...marked only by a door and a sidewalk sign.  Up the stairs we went and were seated in 5 minutes right at the window.  Which was cool because since it was on the second floor no one was staring inside watching us eat. Which always creeps me out and makes me feel uncomfortable and guilty like when I see those infomercials about the orphan kids in Brazil with flies in their eyes. 

Anywho...the food was good.  Garlic Pepper Chicken or Beef are both flavorful and yummy.  The service was pretty quick and efficient though they did get a little confused with the splitting the check three ways. 

It feels like you're eating at someone's house...Comfy and chill.
author: Jay H.

description:
The food is great; the wait is not -- and it's cramped.

The space is small so you may want to avoid typical crowded nights.  Otherwise, the food is decent and it's worth a try.

Lunch is always a great time to go on a weekday.
author: JC R.

description: My friends and I came upon this place based on a recommendation from my tattoo artist. We got the corn cakes, the Penang curry with chicken and the pad thai. All were delicious and decently priced. We were not disappointed. 30 dollars later, with a loosened notch on the belt buckle and some good memories, we walked out of there, satisfied. I would recommend this place if you are in the area. It is very homely and the service is good.
author: Joan S.

description:
Ploy II is the shit. I bet Ploy I was even better and Ploy II was like the ugly sister and killed Ploy I and now there is no Ploy I and just Ploy II. Which is yummy.

Went on Saturday with 5 others. We were shocked(good kind) when our bill was $80 because we had:

BEWARE OF WHITE GIRL PRONUNCIATION:
Pad Kee Mauooo 
Pad Thai w/Shrimp
BBQ Tofu
Spring Rolls
Fried Pumpkin whatever-the-fuck
Beef w/silver noodles
Rice and Beers/wines

That's right you cheap-Os out there. This place is great and affordable. And its on Haight. And its two doors down from Citrus Club (which has gone WAY DOWN HILL and always has a wait....which is so annoying but all the more reason to come to Ploy II. Not I. II.
author: Carrie R.

description:
I can't wait to go to dinner here tonight. I've been a number of times & their red curry with mangoes is absolutely divine!

It had big chunks of mango surrounded by yummy yummy red curry. 

Its also much much food so you end up with some for the next day. Lots of fullness all around. 

Ask to sit by the window. Its a view of the Haight you normally don't see. It interesting to watch the people go by/beg for change/abuse their poor animals/refuse to go back home to their parents in Concord from a distance. 

I can't wait till dinner!
author: Rebekah K.

description:
I don't know what the deal is with Thai food in SF - it being mediocre at best - but the jig is up. Ploy II is good!

First of all, the building is an apartment converted to restaurant so the setting is interesting, quirky and fun. It was pretty busy so I didn't have the depressing feeling of eating in an empty Asian restaurant. And the food was great.

We got a papaya salad, some sweet and sour tofu and some spicy tofu and they were all great. I most definitely made a mental note to come back and try more.
author: C P.

description:
Dined in once, take out twice. YUM. Great fried tofu. Some of the dishes were very sweet, which I don't mind. Had the Pork Phrik-Khing, pork w/ green beans and chili paste, and the Spicy Chicken.  Po-Tak soup, seafood w/ sweet basil, lime, also very good. I can't wait to eat my way thru the menu
 updated 7-27-07
I keep getting food delivered, and always love what I get.
author: C B.

description:
I am not a summer person. This is probably why I refuse to leave the city; I am fortunate to avoid sunlight and humidity for the most part. The heat makes me feel sticky, slimy and downright disgusting. My least favorite thing to do in the heat is to go shopping. Well, I had the day off and I needed some t-shirts. Took the bus to the Haight and did some window shopping. Soon enough, I realized I was hungry, cranky, and too hot to walk any longer. 

The one thing I do enjoy about summer is the idea of meat on a stick. Stuff you'd get at a good friend's bbq or some fair loaded with carnies. Thai food sounded nice and cool and I decided to trek the stairs up to Ploy II. 

Papaya salad and chicken satay to go. As my nemesis Rachael Ray might proclaim: Yum-o!

Perfectly sweet, but tantalizingly spicy, the papaya salad was plentiful and abundant with tomato, green beans, cabbage and peanuts. The satay was perfectly moist and came with peanut sauce I would love to smother myself in (to cool down, of course.) 

The place is quaint. I loved the half-functional christmas lights and the kitschy Thai statues. I didn't eat in, but the take out was a little slower than I was anticipating. They were extremely friendly, though, so I really can't complain too much. Prices were typical.
author: haley d.

description: NEVER order delivery from here! ive been to dine in a couple times, and the food, while nothing spectacular, did the trick. however when we tried to get some delivery on a weeknight, they took 1 HOUR 45 MINUTES from initial order to door buzz. in between, we call twice and were greeted with a very rude employee. we tried to just cut our losses and cancel the order, but they already had charged the card and wouldnt take the cancellation. lame.
author: Carolina S.

description:
Great service, yummy food :)
The tam-ka could have been spicier, so if you like yours a bit hot as well, request that on ordering.

I went with my cousin who had been and we had great service, great food and fab conversation.
My favorite part was it is upstairs, so all the windows face Haight St, making the Asian dining feel even more authentic.

Something I'd never had before, but was amazing:
MIENG KUM                                                                                                           
Spinach leave, dried coconut, dried shrimps, red onions, ginger, limes w/special sauce  ($6.95)
author: sUper j.

description: One of my favorite places to eat in the city now. This place is so bomb! My boyfriend took me here a couple weeks ago and I've already re-visited with my mom. Really friendly service and the set up is really cool! The place is decorated beautifully and you can sit by the windows with a view of the Haight below. Really good food, great prices with huge portions too. Their tom kha, chicken satay and pad Thai are especially amazing! Yumm
author: Alexa F.

description:
It is easy to miss this place as you walk down Haight street so stay sharp.  The restaurant sits on the second floor of this building and is accessed via a stairwell in a bank of 3 stairwells.  

Once inside you get the feeling that someone gutted a flat and turned it into a restaurant.  The food for the most part was very good.  Although my friend and I were both disappointed with the brown rice because it tasted bland and uninspired.  I like the view from the table we had adjacent to the window overlooking Haight street.  It added a sense of serenity to our midday meal.  And an escape from the rat race for even a few minutes is always welcome!

This is a solid 3.5 star restaurant.
author: Richard R.

description:
mmm MMM mmm tasty.

Brilliant house/restaurant design and SCHWEEET service. 2 of my friends were here just a few hours ago enjoying some spicy goodness. Chicken pumpkin curry, spicy prawns with green beans and of course chicken pad Thai all served with steamed rice.... HOLY GOD just the thought of what we ate is going to bleed into my usual dreams of flying through the air then eventually falling and landing in bed with a very hot and randy Natalie Portman as I struggle to take a never ending suite off as she fades away and turns into Max Weinberg holding plates of Chicken Pad Thai and Seafood Red Steamed Curry and everything around me melts away and I'm woken up by my alarm. guh....yeahbuhwhat!?!?

shit dude, this place rocks.
author: Jordan A.

description: This is probably the best Thai place I've been to. Real thai authentic food.. I'm not too fond of those fusion, modern type thai food. Its small and located upstairs of a house but its all good.. I'm into the quality of the food more than anything. Larb gai,  bbq chicken, fried rice, pad se ew, seafood garlic and mango with sticky rice are delish! Definitely recommend!
author: trina g.

description:
For a town where Thai food = cheap noodle joints, it's always great to find a Thai restaurant that isn't one. Ploy on Haight St. is one of these. I've eaten takeout from Ploy many, many times, but the food is best experienced dine-in.  The following dishes are stellar:
1. Imperial rolls
2. Corn fritters
3. Dry beef curry with eggplant
4. Tofu prih-king
5. Spicy duck

It is odd to think that this restaurant used to be someone's house; you're eating in what was probably the living room and dining room.

I'm still looking for a restaurant to replace the late Narai Thai on Clement Street. Ploy comes close.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description: I ordered delivery from Ploy II last week.  A fairly average Thai experience.  Both the barbecue chicken and the vegetarian special plates were filling, but I didn't find myself sad when I finished the leftovers (for breakfast, of course) the next morning.
author: Bill H.

description:
The mango penang curry with prawns is the shit! Big chunks of mango and plenty of prawns. I soooo wanted to NOT finish off the dish since we also had an entree of chicken phad thai as well. My girlfriend and I both failed and kept eating after twice saying we were finished.

Coconut milk was a little odd with ice cubes in it (I prefer Thai Place II's method of just giving you the whole coconut in the shell), but delicious and addicting as well.

It's cramped/cozy/quaint, but we went on Tuesday night and there were open tables. 

I love Thai Place II, but since this is better walking distance it very well may take over the role of my #1 thai place to visit.
author: keith h.

description:
Enough reading about how "I ate here" and "the service was good".  Useless, I tell you. Useless.

Let's talk about soup instead.

First you have to like Tom Ka Gai [sans roaches, see Best of Thai Noodle].  If you don't, stop wasting your time reading this and move on.  

Second, you have to like stories about cutting corners in today's "no-time-to-do-things- correctly-the-first-time-around" world.

If soup is any indication of the quality of the menu, then this place gets a solid 3 stars.  Proper Tom Ka Gai is galangal root, lime grass, coconut milk, and red chili's cooked on a chicken/or vegetable stock base, filtered, then blessed with the tender goodness of white button mushrooms, fresh chicken breast, cilantro, and served in deep steaming bowl with grape tomatoes.

That's an ideal scenario.  We all know what happens with these...

Ploy II sent this ideal scenario the way of other ideal scenarios--think World Peace, boundless space travel, a democratic president--and shat all over this delicious traditional soup recipe by not straining the lemongrass and the galangal in the least [think about eating pungent wood], and *then* tossing in some shitty chicken on a day-old stock that hinted of staleness [you can tell because the coconut milk starts separating after several hours on the stove]. 

Call me an elitist, but I'll be damned if you catch me cutting corners when I cook a bowl of Tom Ka Gai at home.  Which, ultimately, I should do and quit all this bitching about Thai soups.
author: Bartosz S.

description: Loved my first visit, but had some not-so-delicious fried taro root app and waitress said she couldn't take it off our bill even though we barely touched it :( it also said it came with cucumber salad which was mia....otherwise the mango dishes are awesome and staff is friendly...
author: Stephanie A.

description:
Wow. This place was really good. 
Service? Excellent. They seated us as we walked in, moved us when asked, brought water without being asked, took order graciously and quickly, brought food fast, cleared plates on time, brought check on time all politely. 
Food? Excellent. I had spring rolls and poached salmon with black bean sauce. Charles K had chicken and mushroom. The chicken i'd rate 4.5, but the Salmon was really really good. 
Will definitely go back if I'm in the area!
author: Kat C.

description: Great little stumble-upon in the Haight. We were looking for food kind of late and we nearly walked by it, as the signage isn't great. Upstairs is a cosy little restaurant with really great quality Thai food...and it's really reasonably priced too. Fresh herbs, quality ingredients and good service. Yum! We will go back for sure!
author: Koshika S.

description:
I was not impressed.

Okay, the service was alright--although one of the waitresses shoved my friend's (expensive) phone out of the way to make room for a dish (it was sitting on the table, to the right of his plate). The ambiance was fine, but very cramped and the decor cluttered.

The food kinda sucked. I mean, nothing tasted BAD, and it was still better than a lot of food out there. But compared to pretty much all the other sit-down Thai restaurants I've been to in the Bay Area, this was pretty weak.

We got the vegetarian tom kha. Presumably this would be normal tom kha (delicious tangy coconut milk broth, mushrooms, cilantro, lemongrass, onions) with tofu instead of chicken, but what we got was basically VEGETABLES OMG VEGETABLES with a little soup. Broccoli, carrots, cauliflower, etc. Don't get me wrong, I like vegetables, but that's not what I wanted when I ordered the tom kha. There was a bit of tofu in it--though it was the fried kind, which isn't my favorite. The broth was completely bland compared to the other tom kha I've eaten. Also, rather than being creamy and smooth, it appeared to be a bunch of little coagulated chunks of...coconut milk? I don't know. But whatever it was, it was totally not appealing.

We also ordered the tofu yellow curry. Again, PURE VEGETABLES. When I get yellow curry I expect tofu, potatoes, carrots, onions, maybe some peppers, and a lot of yellow curry sauce. Nope, not here.
