Barely any potatoes (my favorite!), barely any tofu. The sauce--what little there was--was more orange than yellow, and nothing to write home about.

We also got the chicken fried rice, and some sort of sweet garlicky tofu thing. They were alright. Nothing terribly exciting. There wasn't very much chicken in the chicken fried rice. I will say that the garlicky tofu thing was pretty tasty and had the proper protein to vegetable ratio (unlike the curry and the soup), but at that point we were so discouraged with everything else that it didn't really make a difference.

So yeah, not going back there. There are a billion Thai places in the Bay Area--why waste time with a mediocre one?
author: Heather H.

description:
I always use the red curry as my gauge for a new Thai experience, and Ploy II has the best red curry I have ever eaten.  Actually, i regretted getting the red curry only because my dining companion got the mango panang curry with prawns.  Out of this world and tempts me to avoid any other Thai place ever again.  

The mango in the mango panang curry is a sweeter take on potatoes or pumpkin, and it works out.  I don't even like prawns that much, but in this spicy sweet and savory sauce with mangos that almost melt in your mouth, it's amazing.  

Masaman chicken comes like none I've ever tried before.  The sauce is a little less thick and it tastes of kefir and lemongrass.  Fantastic, but different.  

Sweet and sour tofu, not so much good.  Haven't tried the pad Thai yet, but may just give up a night of panang....who am I kidding?  I'll never give up my favorite dish from here!

Service is always prompt and friendly, even when they are busy, and it's atmosphere is something different, too.  You're in a second floor apartment, and they just put some extra tables in the living room.  Just pretend it's a family reunion and you all gathered at your uncle Charlie's place in the city and he has just enough room for you.  You'll get to rub elbows with aunt Nelda next to you who likes to leave lipstick kisses on your cheek, and who doesn't want to do that?

It's also affordable and you get a name that inspires storytelling absolutely free.
author: Andrea C.

description: Nice spot for Thai food in charming atmosphere.  Head upstairs and you'll be greeted by a lovely Thai woman who will take you to a seat overlooking the hustle and bustle of Haight Street if you're lucky.  For the food itself though, I like Siam Lotus across the street, though.   Ploy seems overall uninspired and just very basic.   You're here for a cool, unique atmosphere, not the food.
author: John H.

description:
7:30pm: we order delivery, are told "40 minutes." [side note: we are six blocks away]

8:30pm: we call to check on our food, are told "the driver just left, will be there in ten minutes."

8:45pm: we call to check on our food, are told "the driver just left, will be there in ten minutes."

9pm: we call to check on our food, are told "the driver just left, will be there in ten minutes."

9:10: we call to cancel our order, are told we have to wait for the driver to void the credit card transaction. We ask for the manager, who yells at us, tells us we must wait for the driver, then hangs up on us.

9:15: we call back, ask for the manager again, insist that she cancel our order and credit card transaction, she tells us to "wait a few more minutes, the driver is almost there." No, we say, we're not waiting any longer, we're going out. She says, "I'll give you a discount since you already got your food." ???? Now we insist that she cancel our credit card. 

We were still charged for our imaginary order, and are now going through the bank to get our money back. 

WORST NON-SERVICE EVER! STAY AWAY!!!!
author: sarah j.

description:
It felt a little strange walking upstairs into this restaurant. It was as if I were entering someone's home.

I was delighted to find some excellent Thai food inside. Larb and pad see ew were great, as was the service. If I remember correctly, the prices were quite reasonable. I have no complaints about Ploy II.
author: Nathan M.

description:
Ploy 2 is situated on the second floor and is accessible from the street by a single door and staircase.  It looks very much like a gutted/converted flat as the layout is the same to 2nd story flats in the area.

I was able to sample their chicken satay skewers, green curry, and something that reminded me of tofu pad see-ew.  All were good, and moderately priced, the overall dining experience was nice even if the interior of the restaurant was a bit small.
author: Eric L.

description:
This is my favorite Thai restaurant in the city.  Its reasonably priced (even on the cheap side), has a warm atmosphere and is real close to home.  I'd even recommend taking a date here (not a first or second, but maybe a third) because it looks so damn cute inside and the waitresses wear these crazy cool dresses.

If you come here I recommend ordering the Mango Panang Curry with Prawns. I've had it with chicken and its just not as good.  The coconut soup is also pretty damn good, though the bamboo shoots are kind of annoying.

Oh, and I liked the 18 dollar bottle of white wine a lot, but one of my friends didn't. So I guess you have to find that out for yourself...

Happy eating!
author: E-dough R.

description: HANDS DOWN THE BEST THAI IN THE CITY!  I love coming here!  The people are so nice that work here.  It looks sketchy from the outside... walking up stairs in to what seems to be an apt... but I absolutly love the ambiance.  Sitting by the front window is the best because you can watch everyone on the street!  My favorite thing is the Panang Curry. its outstanding.
author: Chelsea S.

description:
Fab, fab, fab!   It's surprising... an obscure restaurant above Haight Street sounds sketchy but I'll never doubt again!  Once we reached the upstairs platform, I was almost bowled over by the tantalizing aromas.  It had a cute decor and a cozy, intimate ambiance, which is hard to find on the streets below.  Everything was scrumptious and satisfying... some of the best Thai food I've had in a long time.  Lesson learned:  You must ascend the steps to reach culinary enlightenment : )

Update:  Silver noodles w/ veggies...uummm...
author: Tara G.

description: Good Food, Great Service, just ignore the decor and hand-written signs. If I was in the hood, I'd go back in a heart beat. The atmosphere.... let's just say it's very haight street. The Restuarant is on the 2nd floor of  what used to be an old Victorian home, and on the homier side. If only I could cook this well in my home!
author: Jennifer K.

description:
I love this place! The food is very authentic, it tastes just like in Thailand.
Definitely try the papaya salad!
The atmosphere is cool too, it's basically an apartment with some of the walls removed.
My favorite Thai place in the city!
author: Tobi K.

description:
Soooo .... 

.... sloooow....

But so good. 

Yellow, red, green curry, all fantastic. The duck was way too fatty, but otherwise, wow. 

The decor in this place is hilarious - it looks like the pattern on my fantasy pair of Onitsukas - golds, bright greens and pinks, shrines, pictures of the Queen, and Christmas lights. It's nice and cozy, located upstairs, elevated from the hustle of the the Haight shopping frenzy.
author: Remy O.

description:
Ploy provides a perfect vegetarian pad thai.  It's a little greasy, a little messy, and comes with a random assortment of steamed vegetables.  Get this, it'll fill you up for under 7 bucks. 

I don't really like dining-in here, I feel like the building is about to collapse, and while I like this place, I certainly don't want to die here.  But that doesn't matter because the to-go service is quick, with a lunch or dinner item ready in about 10 minutes for pickup.

Update: 
Ploy has raised their price to about $8.75 for a pad thai.  This price is unconscionable, therefore they drop from 5 to 3 stars.  Tisk tisk tisk.
author: jack p.

description:
I have always been well served and happy with Ploy 2. 

We showed up there at noon on a Friday and had a good time having the place to our selves for about 10-15 mins, I had never been in the place without it being a moving hum of business. It filled up soon after this. Fun to feel the transition.
 
Beautiful fun place with nice people, Awesome food. 

Good to have brown rice as a choice. 
Happy eating.
author: Tamar K.

description:
Liked this place, but won't highly recommend it. The atmosphere, feels like you are eating in someones living room which is unique. The wait staff seriously risks life and limb each time they bring out a dish, as there is nearly no room between the wait room and the stairwell and they come flying through there traveling from the kitchen to the dining room. 

That may have attributed to this being one of the longest meals I've ever had...got there at 8 & left at 10:30! This was because service is pretty disorganized for the most part. Each dish was brought out 1 at a time, so we were somewhat forced to eat 4 apps and 4 mains family-style. They seemed to not enjoy picking up finished plates either, as each time they would just try to cram the new dish into the middle of the mess and ignore the stack of dishes that was steadily growing until we spoke up and made them take it away. 

There were a few good standouts in the beef salad and the pumpkin curry, but most were typical thai dishes that you can find equal to this at any other thai resturant.
author: Nick V.

description:
SPICY TOFU APPETIZER!!!!!

I love this place. Crunchy deep fried tofu cubes with a tasty sweet and spicy sauce.  Seriously, try the spicy tofu appetizer, you make never think of tofu the same.  Many other good dishes.  Great people.  

Without question my favorite Thai restaurant.
author: Alex T.

description:
After being rejected from Cha Cha Cha's (1 hr. wait) we decided to come here instead, and I'm so glad.

The setting is upstairs, in what appears to be an old apartment or second floor of a house.  The servers are extremely polite and adorable, and catered to everything I asked (no fish sauce, eggs, etc ...)

I've never tried fried pumpkin before, and it was amazing here!  Also good was the pad thai and peanut-tofu skewers.

Hands down the best thai food I've had in SF.
author: Craig R.

description: Very good curry noodle with beef; vegetables were very good, the  soup delicious! 2 Singha beers made this very nice and window seat with perfect service topped off the experience.
author: Owen R.

description:
I love Thai food as much as Vietnamese food. So I came here while on a three day stay in SF a couple of days ago.

This place does not look inviting from the outside. There's a front door with the store sign. Go up the stairs and you feel like you've entered someone's house. Hmmm unique I guess. Since I had been walking around Golden Gate park I was beat. I asked for a glass of water, but ten minutes later still no water. Gosh I was thirsty. Anyhow I'm nice so I didn't complain. 

Here's what I ordered: 

-Papaya salad (good, not too spicy, but not as flavorful as I hoped)
-Tom yum soup with tofu (really good. I'm a sucker for Tom yum soup)
-Pad Thai (good, especially the shrimp. Noodles too al dente for me)
-Pad See-Ew with beef (really good, taste typical with good Thai restaurants)

The Pad Thai and Pad See-Ew had a lot of noodles. More than any other Thai restaurants I've been to so that was a plus. Decent food, decent prices. Just watch out for the baby corns in the Tom yum soup, they might be spoiled.
author: Kim N.

description:
Wam bam, ma'am. I'll give 3.5 stars. My friend and I were titillated with the pineapple-rice photo in the glossy menu. Alas, the rice was served on a dish, and NOT in a pineapple, but it was still damn tasty. The chicken satay was tender, and the yellow chicken curry was above average. Good, clean Thai fix with reasonable prices. 

Over and out.
author: I Love Beef C.

description:
I was pretty hungry after selling CDs at Amoeba yesterday (yes, people, I'm that broke right now, okay - rent and car payment screwed me).  So, my friend was nice enough to get me dinner.  Thanks, Louie! A friend, indeed!  Then again, I was helping him look for shoes and I didn't mind listening to his crazy girl stories.  

Anywho, I'm so good at distracting even myself, huh?!  The food was pretty good.  We had spicy fish (just a tad bit salty though), green beans and chicken, pineapple fried rice, and imperial rolls to start.  The servings were great for two people.  We were pretty filled up and still had to take some of the food to go.  The imperial rolls at Ploy use different wrapping so you may or may not like that.  Other Thai places make imperial rolls with the extra crispy wrapping but Ploy's is worth a try!

I think what I like most about Ploy is the fact that it is just like going to grandma's house (as my good friend pointed out, as you walked up the carpet staircase, it kinda smells like it too).  Although you might experience a bit of claustrophobia upon winding through the tables (beware, don't swing your bag around, you might fling curry in someones face!), the meal will make up for it.
author: Dorothy S.

description:
So delish ! only bad part was ... the crazy stairs to get to the restaurant... Also.... it is very quiet and calm. i had a laughing attack due to all the quietness... i felt like i was like in church. the foood is so delish !! i ordered the pad thai and the other one in menu below that... flat noodles and wow.. so good. 
as appetizer.... i had... the egg rolls. they were so tastey but please wait until they cool down. i was starving and took a huge bite and burned my mouth. this place has excellent service. if u are starving and need food asap, this place is the place to go. Food comes out fast. 
I would definitely go back and eat here. very very good.
author: Berenice D.

description:
Hit-or-miss.  They don't serve the best duck, but their curries and seafood options are pretty good.  The lighting is your standard Victorian-cum-70s-rewiring affair, which always kind of depresses me.  San Francisco Victorians are always so expensive, so why don't people spend a negligible amount and take down the ugly chandelier?

Try the crab noodles.
author: Mike O.

description:
Super charming interior - though a little tight.  Everytime people at the table next to me went to the restroom, they bumped me.

The chicken curry (mild) was delicious and their pad thai was to standards.  Great price for a cute little Thai place :)
author: Wendy T.

description:
I think that in every restaurant, there is a small area like a black hole in which the good customer service disappears. Usually that seating area is near the bathroom or in a corner. 

We got seated in a weird spot where the wall stuck out a bit, so it covered 1/4 of the table from full view. Everyone around us got served first. Even the couple who arrived 10-15 minutes after we sat down - they ordered, ate and left before we got our food. W. T. F.. Srsly...uhm, WHAT THE F$@&.

Right when we were about to walk out after much waiting, they brought over some food. Figures...

Needless to say, we'll probably never be back again.
author: Kay N.

description:
This is one of my favorite Thai places in the city.  The flavors of the food are  very authentic.  reminds me of when i was in Thailand last year.  my favorites from here are the yellow curry, the fried chicken, and the gai gra prow (spicy ground chicken with basil and veggies).  and if you're into the typical noodle plates like pad Thai and pad see you, those are good too.

as you've probably already heard, this place is  the upstairs of a flat converted into the restaurant. no wonder it is so welcoming and "homey".  the waitresses are really nice too and are dressed in authentic Thai garments. oh and the service is good too.  my only complaint is that parking is sometimes hard to find in this neighborhood. but all in all, dope spot

good food+good service+good atmosphere= one happy Lalo
author: Lalo G.

description:
Some of the best Thai food I've ever had!

they have the absolute best vegetarian selection I've ever seen in a Thai restaurant, not to mention a hell of a thai iced tea! The portions are huge, so much so that i've unfortunately had to omit dessert each and every time I've come, and all of their dishes are so completely unique that its a completely different experience each and every time I've come; very refreshing.

Now about the Service: Although it doesnt look like much from the outside, this place happens to be my favorite lunch & dinner spot on Haight. Not only do they captivate a very authentic thai atmosphere during dinner with the traditional costumes worn by the waiters and waitresses, they also deliver great customer service! The wait-staff are extremely sweet!

I deffinitely reccomend coming here if your ever in the neighborhood and craving some Thai :]
author: Mercedez P.

description:
This place is upstairs in a converted Edwardian flat, so it feels like you're eating in a friend's living room instead of on Haight Street. Definitely a good thing.

The food was slightly above average for SF Thai, I'd say. We had a Spicy Duck that was excellent--although in my book it's hard to mess up duck--if a bit oniony. Cashew Tofu with chili was also good, sweet but not overly so, with a nice firmness to the tofu. Sticky rice was served with each serving individually wrapped in tinfoil, an environmentally insensitive practice I've never seen anywhere else.

Service, unfortunately, was a problem. Oh, they were friendly and reasonably attentive and kept us supplied with water; no problem there. However, while the Spicy Duck dish I described above was good, it was not what we ordered. Since we enjoyed it, we didn't send it back, but it's better to get what I ask for in restaurants, generally speaking. Also, we had leftovers of two separate dishes, and they just dumped them both into the same takeout container. I suppose if you're not too picky about your sauce-mixing, it could be OK, and maybe they were trying to make up for the wastefulness of the tinfoiled rice, but I prefer to have two takeout dishes boxed separately, thanks. Isn't that common sense?
author: Mark G.

description: Ploy II is my favorite restaurant of all time. It has very good vegetarian options (Tofu Praram and Tofu Prig King) and amazing rice dishes, curries and soups as well. I highly recommend this place.
author: Ariane E.

description:
I get cravings for this place! And we have been there so often, they all know us when we walk in the door.

The veggie fresh rolls are unparalleled anywhere (just try to find anything like them anywhere... I dare you!). We call ahead a few hours and reserve them, because they sell out every night!

The green curry is the best in San Francisco (yes, miles better than Phuket) and their vegetable salad is so fresh and light and tasty... 

The wine is cheap, but good, and this is the perfect place to eat out on a date, or with friends. Go there. Eat. You will not be disapppointed!
author: Annie B.

description:
This Thai food is delicious, served in good sized portions and reasonably priced.  Eat some.  

I order it for delivery, which is slow, but worth the wait.  Just order ahead (i.e. an hour or more) of when you think you'd like to eat.  Even with the wait, the food has arrived hot and tasty every time.
author: Sean G.

description: Nice place, not 4-star. I am picky when it comes to Thai, and no place gets 5-star outside of Siam. That said, Ploy II doesn't come close in terms of food. The service does though and I really like employees, but food wise, this is Americanized Thai at its best/worst. The soups are high calorie meals one would not find on any Thai persons table. The dishes lack spice and the curries are bland. My friends would kill me if they read this, because they love it, but let's face the truth here, this really isn't real Thai food. Still it is good, and I really like the workers, but I promise you this: The Thai workers here DO NOT eat the food they serve without altering it first to their tastes. I joked once, give me what you eat, and they laughed.
author: Brian J.

description:
Before Mekong, this was my favorite Thai place. I still love it though. It is right in the mix of Haight Street shopping and hard to see from the street as you have to walk up a flight of stairs.

I would recommend ordering the Spicy Tofu Combination Entree and the fried taro appetizer with the yum sweet dipping sauce. The yellow curry is also very good.

The staff is very friendly and they wear pretty Thai dresses.  The restaurant can get crowded and like others have mentioned, the tables are set up in a way that you can be pretty cramped.  They make up for this by having very cheap house wine! $2 or $3. Nice. You can also get it by the carafe.

Fun place, good food, friendly and very reasonably priced in a good location.
author: Laura V.

description:
This place is just alright.

The experience we had here the other night was kind of hellish. And by hellish, i mean it was like 90 degrees in there and the bill was all jacked up. Oh and service was pretty slow. They did however get our food out in a good amount of time.

We ordered the Tofu Pad See Ew and it was quite tasty, it's pretty much tasty anywhere you go so I guess it's not too special. Had the BBQ Chicken dish, but it was pretty bland. I asked for a single order of rice, they brought a whole pot... which they of course charged us for.

Yeah, it was just not very good on many levels... It is however right next to our house, so it's pretty convenient.
author: Richard T.

description:
Atmosphere. Great Food. Excellent Service. 

This place has ALL of that; probably why it's my new favorite place to dine in San Francisco.

It sorta feels like a little "hidden spot" because the sign outside is so unassuming, but open the door and walk up the stairs and you're treated to a SEVERELY affordable meal in a super-cozy atmosphere (complete with fireplace, curtains, all that). The service is great and the food is delicious. 

I kind of don't want the masses to discover this place...leave it for me! haha

I have only been let down ONE time, and that's when I ordered tea and it was just a tea bag thrown in the cup....not very impressive for an Asian restaurant. 

Regardless, I LOVE THIS PLACE! Take a date! Perfect for it (and cheaper than you'd expect).
author: Danyell K.

description:
My wife and I are always looking for a new Thai place to check out whenever we visit the various neighborhoods around the city. We stumbled across Ploy II's front porch about 3 years ago and have made it back a total of 5 times. So far we've had the Vegitarian Egg Rolls, the Pad Thai Noodles, Pad See Eew, Panang Curry (my new favorite) and the Tom Ka Gai. We usually judge a Thai restaurant by it's Pad Thai noodles and this place has the best recipe!

The setting is almost as enjoyable as the food. The restaurant is located on the second floor of a two story flat which has been converted to a full service restaurant. The dining room sits in the front of the flat located in the double parlor. There isn't much elbow room, but despite the cramped quarters, you will dine comfortably. All in all, this place has all the charm you could hope for in the Haight, and will definitely satisfy your need for some Pad Thai! Seriously, it's delicious.
author: Omar M.

description: If you are looking for an authentically prepared Thai meal with super attentive service by gracious and lovely servers, you won't be sari, I mean "sorry". You'll be clapping your hands because you will be "happy"! The owner, Sunee came by to check to see if everything was okay. We highly recommend Spicy Chicken Wings that were so sweet and spicy and crunchy, just fabulous! The Fresh Springs rolls with Ginger Sauce were so fresh and tasty! We shared an entree of Spicy Basil Chicken with Prawns and asked for a 7/10 and it was so spicy and delicious. You cannot miss!
author: Manny A.

description: I kid you not, I order here about once a week, if that. In love with their food, and their customer service level is outstanding! Not gunna lie....I am all about the Green Curry...and their Fresh Spring Rolls. I highly recommend this place, whether that be delivery, take-out, or simply dining in. Love you Ploy II, you made my SF experience unforgettable.
author: Kelly Z.

description:
Fantastic!

Look for the sign... head upstairs... order the mango curry... leave happy!
author: Danger R.

description: Decent food - we've tried food delivery from here a couple of times. Delivery was on-time. Well-sized portion sizes, noodles are not too greasy. I wish they were a bit less stingy in their use of basil in pad kee mao (drunken noodles).
author: Shweta V.

description:
So, where's Ploy 1?

I like this place because they are pretty no frills - seems like a haight street apartment converted into a restaraunt - gives a very comfortable dining experience you can't get at most restaraunts these days. 

also the food is affordable and always delicious.
author: Liam D.

description:
I once wrote this about Mexican food.  People get so incredibly passionate about their favorite place.  "This is the BEST Thai place.  It's SOOO much better than Siam King, King Siam, and it absolutely DESTROYS King Phuket of Siam."

Whatever.

If you have a craving for Thai, Ploy II won't disappoint.  Though they did seem to have an awkwardly high ratio of onion to other stuff in pretty much every dish.  But again, whatever.  It's fine.

One star for the sticky rice with mango, which brought back so many great memories of this great dessert just to remind me how one can butcher pretty much anything.

Then again, five stars for watching my Indian friend shamelessly call out every Thai word he knew at the ever-so-patient staff.  So that makes three stars, right?

I hear Lotus Siam is better.  Or was that Siam Lotus?  Hrmph...
author: Daniel D.

description:
Ploy II does it right.  I never knew it existed until my friend came into town and wanted to grab thai food in the Haight.  I couldn't remember ever seeing a thai place on Haight street.  The reason I never noticed is because it is tucked away on the second floor of an old Victorian.  The restaurant is quaint and transports you back in time.  

We had a great dinner of pad thai and panang curry.  The pad thai was really good!  Lots of veggies, delicious, tender chicken, and just the right amount of sauce.  The curry was also delicious.  We asked for it mild (spicy food gives my friend the hiccups) but it was still spicy.  She definitely was hicupping.  The curry was very flavorful with that perfect combination of sweet and spicy.  

The portions were generous and the price was right.  I'll be back!
author: Zoe H.

description: Though i love this place for the cosy atmosphere and the food, this rating is for the service. On my last visit we were really disgusted with the place coz of their extreme slow service.. There were only 2 servers to manage all the tables even at their busiest time. The place was completely packed, so the two poor girls were on their toes at all time. After we were seated we waited for long and finally had to call one of the staff to take our order. Then again had to call just to remind that we ordered our food way long time back. Once the food is kept at the table, NO Plates!! Wait again to remind someone to get the plates.. HELL this place is a total chaos with too less staff to manage!! Go to this place if you have all the time in this world..
author: Payal B.

description:
Will never eat here again.

I got a delivery from Ploy last night and it ruined my evening. 

I ordered the Thai chicken noodle soup and it was a major disappointment. All I wanted was the simple goodness of chicken broth and rice noodles. The soup was greasy, bland, and generic. No subtle flavors, no fresh aromatics. As another review said about another soup, it tasted like Bouillon cube. The only thing fresh were some chopped green onions.

My friend had the green curry with chicken and found it watery, bland, and generic. The imperial roles were overdone and had no fresh garnish of any kind. 

In addition, the delivery arrived with no utensils, napkins, etc.

I agree with other yelp reviews that have clocked this place as a Thai restaurant for tourists who don't know what good Thai food tastes like.
author: Paul P.

description:
I've been patronizing Ploy since back in the highschool ages of 96'-97'.

Ploy again has been consistent never changing it's taste. I like that. I especially like their corn cakes and of course tom ka.

Yes, Ploy you are the best!~
author: Adrienne H.

description:
My favorite Thai restaurant in the city!  Delicious vegetarian dishes with tofu and lots and lots of veggies.  The food is always tasty, the servers are super friendly, and the prices are reasonable.

I really love this place!
author: Lisa W.

description:
By far my favorite Thai restaurant in the city!  

Price- Very cheap!! With appetizer, entree, drink, etc- 12-15 bucks a person-ish.  

Decor- Very chill, authentic look to the place.  You really come here for the food and nothing else.  It's super cozy, it's actually a house upstairs converted into a restaurant.  I probably walked by this place about a hundred times b4 I figured out it was a restaurant.  

Food-  Pumpkin Curry, Pineapple Fried rice,  Tom Kha, Mango sticky rice, spicy fish, Phrik Khing are my favorites.  

If you're looking for foo foo, try that Osha place everybody likes.  Like I said, it's a converted home- restaurant, so the area is pretty tight, but chill out and eat the food, it's great!!!
author: Chase F.

description:
There was a lack of motivation to cook at home as my boyfriend and I walked down Haight from the Gold Cane.  We took some folks' recommendation on this cute little Thai restaurant.

I liked the spring rolls. I liked the pumpkin curry with tofu. I liked the generous portions. The spicey-ness was spicey enough ( I got the red pumpkin curry) but I'm the type that likes to cry when eating spicy food so it could have had a tiny bit more kick. 

But I just *liked* it. I didn't love it. I still think Marnee Thai is better. But I'm willing to give it a second chance.
author: Meghan L.

description:
I been there 2 or 3 times and I can't compain. It is as good as it is!

Nice, warm homelike athmosphere, food is really tasty, portions are large enough, friendly servers.
Place is just fine as for casual eat out, as for the date. 

If you happen to be in that area and just craving for some Thai - that's my 2 thumbs up for you!
author: Cat of a Donut J.

description: I wanted Pad Thai, they sold it. It was yummy, not better than any other that I've had and not worse. I'd probably come back if i were in the area. It's an upstairs restaurant and the prices are low but they had a menu at the door that shows lower prices than the menu upstairs..Arbitrary or non-updated prices are my pet-peeve.
author: Chris H.

description:
Hands down best thai food in the city.  Everything on the menu is good, and even on a busy night, the service is consistent.  Neither amazing or terrible, just a bunch of lovely ladies doing their job. 

Best things on the menu: Fresh spring rolls (come early for these, they ALWAYS run out), Mango panang curry, and Pad Thai.

Everything else on the menu is delicious but those are definitely the best.  THey have really good thai iced tea as well.

But don't tell too many people about this place or you'll end up having to wait for a table.
author: Alexandra A.

description:
The fifteen minute mark was approaching as I waited for my takeout order, which seemed too long in a mostly empty thai spot where I had been promised my food in 10. Dismissive service wasn't helping. Ploy was dangerously close to slipping from three to two stars. The mental yelp was being written...

The BBQ chicken not only saved the experience, but earns Ploy a fourth star. The chicken was boneless, seemed to have a minimal amount of oil and it was cut, meaning yours truly didn't have to do it at home. And the portion size was awesome, plenty to snack on the side as well as fill a thai-themed burrito I made back at home.

Ultimately worth the wait, and at less than $10, a great deal.
author: Jason B.

description: It took a rave recommendation from a friend and some serious internal debate for me to try Ploy II instead of heading to nearby (and oft-frequented) Citrus Club, but I'm glad I made the choice to diversify. The peanut sauce is not to be missed, and their yellow curry is the best I've had in years. The quirky, living room-esque environment manages to come off as charming, even if it can be a bit crowded. Citrus Club now has serious competition for my affections (and business.)
author: Lindsay J.

description:
Came up to a quaint little restaurant.  Looks really expensive, but after a lookover of the menu we're relieved that it's not.  Get seated.

10 minutes later, finally get our order taken.

40 minutes later, finally get our food.  

My friend and I both ordered beef Praram with Peanut Sauce, described as " Your choice of meat with sweet and creamy peanut sauce served over spinach".  We each receive a very small plate.  On each very small plate was a very small serving of beef with peanut sauce... or so we thought.  Instead it was actually a TINY serving, like 3 tablespoons, carefully spread over a GIANT LUMP of cabbage to disguise its true teensiness.  Funny how they didn't mention cabbage (oh the cheapest of veggies!) the the description, considering we got 3 times more cabbage than beef.  OMG... They tricked us!

And what of the spinach?  The three strands of spinach hidden like jewels betwixt the minor cornucopia of cabbage were so tough and old I literally choked on its way down.  

After this "meal", we were both ravenous within the hour.  Boo.
author: Monica W.

description: I was not that impressed with this place. The organization is confusing with regard to seating. When we walked upstairs to be seated, we didn't know what to do or who to talk to. Everything was chaotic. Once we got our food I was not pleased with the flavor of our dishes. They were a bit bland and I ended up complimenting mine with a sizable amount of hot sauce. I learned that the Haight is not a place one should go for cuisine.
author: Michael G.

description:
Deep fried pumpkin. Holy shit.

That is all. I love you, Ploy.
author: Ryan B.

description:
Ploy II is my favorite take-out Thai in San Francisco. Everything they make is filled with flavor, and I appriciate their careful use of spices to accentuate the food, not overpower it. My usual is crab fried rice and chicken yellow curry, a one-two punch of yummy in my tummy. It's also fun to eat inside the restaurant because it really feels like you're in someone's dining room. I like looking down upon the hipsters of Haight street.

Allow me to share my favorite Ploy II experience; There was a young park rat outside with his dog asking for change as usual when we walked in to Ploy II. Then, as I looked outside while waiting for my satay to arrive, I saw the same kid pull car keys from his pocket and drive away in a Land Rover Discovery that was parked across the street. It was one of those moments when I felt like I was just let in on one of the great jokes of the universe, a glimse into the devine comedy if you will. I couldn't stop laughing throughout our dinner and afterwards all the way home.
author: Tal K.

description:
Every time I eat at Ploy 2 I always feel like I'm dating some Thai chick and I'm over at her parents house for dinner. 

Obviously the place is a converted house but it kinda goes beyond that for me. I guess it's the home style plates, glasses, and table settings they use, I can't put my finger on exactly what it is but I like it. 

Aside from the homey feel of the place the food is awesome, the prices are perfect for someone on budget and it usually doesn't take to long to get a seat. 

Keep on keepin on Ploy 2 and I'll keep on pretending I'm dating some Thai chick who's parents live in the Haight.
author: Tommy P.

description:
Yay for eating upstairs in someone's apartment! It was a pleasant surprise to walk into this place and see a regular, residential kitchen. I would have pulled up a seat at the kitchen counter if they let me.

Oh and the food's tasty, too. Really cheap fried green pumpkin and green papaya salad on the specials menu were very good. The other food was good too. I'm sure other places in the city have food that's just as good, but the coziness of the restaurant/apartment and friendly ladies who work there make this place stick out. I'll be going back.
author: Rachel H.

description: I have been here a few times. Located in a small little nook which was formerly a home on Height Street, this place is delicious. The fried spring rolls were perfect. So far, the best I have had in the city. The red chicken curry was pretty decent, but the bamboo shoots in it were bizarrely large. The Phad Thai was regular. The only complaint really, was the service. We were the only ones here and waited WAY to long to order and to get our check. That, and the table behind us was sitting full of leftover food and garbage from the guests before us the entire time we were there. Gross. I will still keep this place as my Thai food standby, the service was still very nice.
author: Jena D.

description:
I came here spur of the moment with a couple of friends right before an art show close by. My first impression... dude its a house LOL. Rather quaint but still this is or was a house (fireplace intact) lol. 

The waitresses were pleasant enough and served us quickly. I ordered the Curry Noodles with prawns, it was actually better than I thought it would be. Had lots of prawns (compared to other places, where they give like 3 pieces) and broccoli (my favorite veggie) and a bunch of other veggies in there as well. Only I didn't think it would have that much of a bite to it, but once you get past that, its excellent.  

I actually wanted to try the fried banana and ice cream dessert but by the time I was done with my noodles, I couldn't eat anymore lol. So I'm definitely coming here again (this time with more room for dessert).
author: Linda X.

description: loved it, really nice service, good authentic thai food and they made it nice and spicy as per our request.
author: F S.

description: Their mango panang curry is possibly the greatest sauce I've ever tasted... Worth every penny! I love this place...  Their Tom Kha is to die for too.
author: Andre M.

description:
I like this place. The food is tasty and pretty reasonably priced. The atmosphere is... homie. Not the best Thai in the city but not bad and a nice place to sit and eat.

For my folks out there... this may have been the first Thai place, besides my friend's joint that I ate at for like 5 years, that didn't give me an attitude while serving. Honestly, there are two kinds of Thai servers i've encountered:
1. I'm Thai and I wait tables in the US
2. I'm Thai, wait tables in the US , and I hate this fact because I'm waaaayyyyyyy too important to serve these negroes but this job pays under the table so I'll do it but I'll make sure you all suffer while I'm here!

Ploy II has the cool kind. The new Osha on 2nd has the other kind.
author: Selino V.

description:
This place was quite good, I've had better pad thai but the Panang Curry was incredible.  It is on the second floor of a house and you feel like you are eating in someone's living room, its a neat space, nothing fancy, just real cozy.  

I'd go back for the Panang....
author: Casie M.

description:
Food is ok, at best.  Friends have eaten here, as well, but have stopped because they felt the food was not the best quality.

Their service is similar.  I ordered for delivery and called two times.  Still after 2 hours, no delivery.  

When I called back the woman yelled at me for them not finding where I lived and hung up on me (she stated they called me but I had my cell phone and there is no indication a call was missed).  

I've been a patron of this place for 5 years and all I had to have was  a person who cared about my business and a kind apology.  So now after being a patron for 5 years, I will no longer bring friends to this restaurant and the delivery menu is in the recycling bin.  I guess this family just doesn't know what it means to have exemplary customer service... or even passible service, for that matter!

Go to Chilli Cha Cha instead, the food is of exceptional quality and they actually can find your house!
author: Ernest M.

description: We're pretty new to the hood & Ploy II delivers & is within walking distance. I'd say 3 & 1/2 stars, but to be upfront have yet to find a 5-star Thai place in SF. Love the fact that they deliver, but as is the case with all delivery, it's better if you eat in.  I'm an egg eatin', fish sauce shunnin' vegetarian, and they have always gotten that right, so that earns them at least an extra 1/2 a star in my book. They don't lean to the spicy side, but if you order spicy, it will come with some tasty burn. Still not close to what I think of as "Thai spicy," but tasty.  The red curry, fresh spring rolls, thom ka, pad se ew, and all things served on a sizzling plate have been good. And drinking the fresh coconut is tasty & fun.
author: Marybeth S.

description: One of my favorites Thai places in the city.  It is  a tuck away gem on Haight Street.  The decor is definitely very homey since its looks like a living room from a Victorian in Alamo Square. The food is delicious. On my recent trip I ordered the corn fritters to  start, the thai basil pork, and rice. All three items were good, and the service is top notch.
author: Miranda m.

description: This place was much better than I expected!  It's in what looks like an old apartment, which is funny but kind of endearing.  My friend introduced me to these weird spinach wrap things with dried shrimp, nuts, and a sweet sauce - they were delicious!  My green curry was tasty, her pad see ew was fine.  It's not as good as Marnee Thai, but it's less crowded, very cheap, and well worth a visit if you're in the Haight!
author: Rosie R.

description:
Yummy, authentic Thai food. The servers are sweet, and they are always wearing pretty Thai dresses. It's fun and cozy upstairs, eating dinner on the 2nd floor of the house and w/ the authentic decor, the whole experience is really fun. Their prices are pretty average, and you can get a bottle of wine for under $20, or a carafe of house wine for under $15. 
If you're looking for brown rice, they have that, too. 

Ooh, it's all so yummy! I am hungry just thinking about Ploy II.
author: Amy J.

description: I called for a delivery order, placed my order well over $15 per the website, told them I'll be paying cash.  After 52 minutes I got a call from the restaurant that the driver will not deliver my food because I live too far from the restaurant.  Why did they NOT tell me this when I placed the order - 52 minutes BEFORE? I live in Pacific Heights, 2.1 miles from the restaurant - according to Google Maps.  They did not deliver and they will not be getting any business from me.
author: lissagma l.

description: This place is a piece of shit. I ordered and was told that my food would be there within 45 minutes. After two hours of waiting, and two calls later, I was aggressed by both an employee and the manager. I never got to taste the food, but they have TERRIBLE  customer service.
author: Clément B.

description: They have the sweetest pad thai I have ever had. Yum! it was served on a big plate and looked like a lot of food but i finished it all so maybe not? They have a really homey atmosphere and it really feels like you're eating in someone's second floor home.
author: Helen L.

description:
Went to this place after a few drinks at Alembic, it's a converted flat, which is creative, but makes for tight quarters.  The place is decorated quaintly and the servers add a nice flare dressed in traditional clothing.  

We ordered a few hot and cold dishes to share and although the food is cheap and the service friendly, it's not my favorite Thai place. I wouldn't trek across the City for it, but would possibly go if I were back in the neighborhood.
author: Tamz O.

description:
Ploy II! Ploy II! This is my friend's favorite Thai restaurant. I kindly refer to it as "that Thai restaurant in the Haight with the narrow stairs, tiny wait area, cramped seating and statues of ladies in colorful clothing." 

I first ate here a while ago with my friend, and sampled a number of dishes all of which I liked very much. I can't wait to go back again, but the last few times I've been in the Haight, or there's been mention of "Thai food in the City," it's been closed due to remodeling.
author: Amy D.

description:
If you miss this place while you're walking by, you're not alone.  I used to live on the other side of the panhandle for a while and always walked by but never saw this place.  Its right across the street from Kan Zaman, and look up; Its the upstairs of an old Victorian.  The place is surprisingly uncluttered and felt larger than I expected.  The layout...well its a Victorian...waiting in the hall, and seating in the living and dining rooms; never saw the bedrooms.

Got the following:
-duck over spinach ...the duck was good, a step up from the dry crappy duck I had last week
-eggplant tofu...no complaints
-mango curry with shrimp...lots of mango which I originally though was really soft potatoes, since I wasn't there when we ordered
-fried fish...Didn't pay attention what kind of fish but it was delicious.

All this and dessert...ice cream and fried something.....this time I wasn't listening

All great food and good service...the food came out quick and the waitress was friendly and helpful...all this including desert for less than 60 bucks.  Next time you're in the Haight check out Ploy II.  On a random side note, I think there was a Thai movie called Play that was released at  Cannes earlier this year.  And bring a jacket, its freaking cold.
author: Summit S.

description:
You would never think that this was on the Haight.  The dirty, overpriced, fast food haight.

Up a steep and very narrow stairway, there is a cozy little place to eat.  It is like going to a friend's family's place to eat upstairs in their victorian home.  Modest, friendly, warm.  

I had the Tom Yum Noodle Soup and it was good.  Not like the packages Thai Noodles that I've been known to eat in times of weakness.  The broth was soothing.  The Thai Iced tea was perky.  What makes it that atomic orange color?  How do I make it at home?

There were ants on the table.  They weren't going after my food so i wasn't too bothered about them but I kept wondering where they were coming from.  The flowers were all fake so it couldn't have been from those.  Or the hanging plastic plants.  At first there were three.  Then two.  Then there were 5.  

The experience was quiet, service was quick, and I am very full now.  $6.50 for a bowl of noodles and soup.  Much better priced than I'd expected.  I like lunch specials.  The dinner service starts at 4pm.  I added an extra star because I was going to order take out but the minute I walked in, I wanted to sit down, open my book and read a little.  It was inviting, even to the lone diner like me.

UPDATE: Maybe my stomach wasn't used to eating food let alone greasy-ish food so as of now, it still is not agreeing with my lunch.  The soup was a little oily but I didn't think it would be a problem.  I just hope it goes away, this feeling.  It is not food poisoning but rather food undigesting.
author: Christina C.

description:
I've made it a personal mission to eat at the strip of Thai restaurants off Haight in my neighborhood. 

I have frequently ordered out from Ploy II and they are always consistent. 
Usually avoid eating there because its cramped but I do like the cozy space.
I love the fried tofu here, I don't know what it is about the coating and brittle basil. Mmmm......its kind of like tofu junk food. 
Most importantly, I LOVE LARB. I admit it freely.
(larb, larb, larb, larb, la la la)
The only option at many places is chicken larb. OK, done.
But why is the chicken larb always dry? It just ruins it a little bit for me.
It is an epidemic. 
/end rant/
Delicious green curry and mango sticky rice for dessert.
I also really like their soups. I haven't had anything I wouldn't recommend.
Perfect for an evening at home with the movie projector & a bottle of wine. 
In summary: the food here is like the interior of the restaurant, cozy & warm in my belly.
author: Claire S.

description:
I absolutely loved this place, BUT you need to be in the mood for that particular kind of environment.  

The food was delicious. We had Tom Kha soup and Satay Chicken, pretty reliable staples of the Thai dinner world. Both were very yummy. Prices were very reasonable. 

But what really made the experience was the adorable nature of the place.  From Haight, all you see is a sign for Ploy and a door, which looks questionable.  You go inside and up some stairs to the actual restaurant, which is adorable, with a nice mix of natural and lamp lighting.  It feels like a delicious hideaway. 

Highly recommended for anyone looking for a moderately casual Thai dinner experience.
author: Eugenee H.

description: The food was good. The service was average. The atmosphere was a bit crowded. I'd go back there again for casual dining, but it won't become a favorite of mine.
author: Jessica R.

description: Me and a friend enjoyed the food, service, view and price. She ordered fried tofu and vegetables, and I had red curry with pork, we both took tea with our meal and had mango and sticky rice for afters. Delightful. I would like to eat at the kitchen counter next time :D
author: Satoshi K.

description:
Ploy II offers the best Thai food in the warmest environment available in the Upper Haight. The restaurant itself is a converted, upstairs Victorian apartment with all the woodwork and wainscoting of some of San Francisco's finest homes. With touches of Thai culture added all about, this cozy restaurant offers amazing authentic dishes at affordable prices.

In truth, I never eat in the restaurant. It's proximity to my apartment makes it my Number One choice for pick up dinner, or even delivery when it's too cold outside or I'm too lazy to get off of the couch.

I almost always get the same thing: Veggie Thai Egg Rolls and the Mango-Prawn Panang Curry with rice. The rolls offer a hot and crisp beginning to one of my favorite take-out meals. Whatever is inside them- some vegetable or mushroom- tastes great with sweet and sour sauce drizzled over it.

The Mango-Prawn Panang Curry is something to behold. It's chock-full of prawns and huge chunks of hot mango. It is the best Panang Curry I know of in the city and the special, off-menu choice of mango and prawns makes it a unique dish in a city filled with options.

Other menu options I have tried have also been delicious: the Tom Yum soup is a classic, and the Pad Thai is as good as any.

This place is my comfort food haven. Enjoy.
author: Ben R.

description:
Ploy II is good good good! I discovered it randomly one day in the midst of a tiring upper haight shopping spree. I'd definitely say its one of the top dinning choices in the entire neighborhood. I don't know if it's just me, but I typically find a lot of haight street eateries to have a sort of dirty feel to them...well Ploy II is a real exception to that.

I love how the restaurant is situated in the top floor of an old victorian, over looking the street below. It's so charming and quaint! You don't see many thai restaurants quite like it, just based on atmosphere alone. But the food is also exceptional...the pad thai is delicious! Some of the best pad thai I've ever had, actually, I would say. Full of flavor and perfectly balanced. 

I've also tried a few of their appetizers, which I was less fond of, namely the fried pumpkin (too heavy!). I don't remember loving the fried banana, either, but I do think that a lot of the main courses are really outstanding!
author: Shannon R.

description:
...Always  a good experience, and the food is consistently good.

The larb has just the right amount of 'stinky' for me.

This place has a nice atmosphere for dinner with a group of friends (4-6ish).  It's mellow enough to talk, but the decor and the waitresses in the silk asian dresses make it a little more fun than average.

Service is so-so. I've definitely had to wait a while for my food and/or my check before.
author: Angelo B.

description:
I was so tired at the time and hungry. When I saw Ploy II on the 2nd floor of the building, I thought it better be good if they making me clime this stairs. 

It was Friday late lunch, around 3pm_I think.  Quite empty.

I ate Tom Yum Goong Noodle Soup with pork. They put a stuffed fried won ton on top with Thai source - it was very tasty. Pork was quite tough but the flavor was very good so I gave 3 stars. 

There were only a few other couples but they all look comfortable and fine with their food. I would try again to eat their curry.
author: Green Mango Y.

description:
I love the concept of a flat remodeled into a restaurant!  

By plain view, one would think that someone is having dinner parties in their upstairs apartment all the time.  The space is limited, and expect a wait.  But the servers are good about moving people in and out, and the food comes out quick.

The food is reasonably priced, and down right good!  I love their green curry.  It's so creamy, with a nice kick of spiciness.  I believe that this is one of the best green curries that I have had, besides the avocado green curry at Araya's in Seattle.  

For years I have been strolling Haight, and only did I notice Ploy when I was waiting in line at the Red Vic.

This place is too cute and cozy!  And the food is exceptional!
author: Sheri N.

description:
Easily the worst Thai Food I have ever eaten.  I am not a hater I swear....maybe I was there on an off day or something.

II ordered the spicy noodles....The pumpkin curry wasn't available because the manager had just returned or some crappy excuse.

So Spicy Noodles with Chicken it is.  40 Minutes later a plate of very rubbery noodles and pressed flat rubber chicken landed on my table.  Oh yeah...and there were shrimp in it.  Not being a shrimp fan I asked the nice waitress to send it back.....it came back to my table and it was as though they just picked out the shrimp.  So I reordered some Thai Fried Rice with chicken.  

I got Burnt Fried Rice with the same rubber chicken.  I tried to choke it down....but I just couldn't do it.  And I usually will eat just about anything.  We paid...left a tip (at least the waitress was nice) and went to get pizza or anything else.

I had been here before and it was ok....not great....not bad.  So I was hoping it would hold fair...no such luck.
author: joshua c.

description:
Ordered delivery from here a few nights ago 
Masaman Mango Curry - amazing
Pad Thai with Shrimp - good, nothing too amazing 

I will probably order a few more curries from here 
The wait was about an hour
author: john q.

description: Cheap, yummy and great service. The menu is HUGE and I got really overwhelmed with the choices so I played it safe and ordered shrimp pad thai. The service was very no-nonsense, fast and friendly. I like how it looks inside too. Very unconventional layout - kind of like rooms in a home. The decor is so cheesy and fun! Lots of sparkly masks, trinkets and christmas garland. There was hardly anyone else there so we got a great people-watching table overlooking Haight. Definitely going back to this place!
author: M M.

description: The chicken panang curry is the best I have ever had in any city, in any Thai restaurant. Pad thai is solid, thai iced tea is teeth shakingly sweet. Great find.
author: Sabbies B.

description:
So I have been searching for a Thai delivery in the Haight for about a year now. I was finally turned on to Ploy II and I have fallen in love!

I have never eaten in the restaurant, in fact I have no clue where it is but all of their food is amazing! I always order the Tom Yum, Fresh Spring Rolls and Mango Panang Curry. If I am feeling festive I will also get the deep fried pumpkin...mmmmmmmm. The only downside I have with them is that if you don't order before 6 or 7 pm they will be out of the fresh spring rolls. 

I highly recommend this place for delivery. You will be truly satisfied!
author: Annalee H.

description:
After sampling both Marnees, I was excited to give Ploy a run. I ordered two of the exact same dishes to make it interesting. The rundown:

Round 1: Veggie Tom Yum 

Good size serving, plenty for two. Lots of veggies. However, tom yum is supposed to be lime-y, lemongrass-y, and spice-y. This was none of that. It was a sweet liquid with veggies in it. Bummer dish.

Winner: Marnee, hands down

Round 2: Corn cakes

First of all, about 30 min passed before they realized we had ordered more than just the soup. The service was WAY off. To make matters worse, the cakes had clearly been par-fried in advance and re-fried upon our order. I immediately wondered when they were originally fried. My guess is last Tuesday. Then, since they had forgotten about us, we had the additional pleasure of eating lukewarm-heat lamped-twice-fried dry, overcooked corn cakes. BLECH. It is fucking hard to ruin fried corn.

Winner: Marnee, for knowing how to deep fry shit

3rd dish: Mushroom Salad

High hopes, low flavor. It was fine. Especially compared to the other messes. 

4th dish: Veggies and tofu in peanut sauce

Again with the sweetness? It is not my weakness - in THAI food!!! Blech. Terrible excuse for peanut sauce. It's like the cook here doesn't use any spices other than sugar.

The whole visit was a disappointment - the service was indifferent to bad. They suggested how to pace our dishes, we agreed, but then the dropped off soup for 30 minutes and crowded the table with our 3 dishes all at once. Not that we actually wanted to eat any of them anyway.

I'm glad I tried Ploy, after all the hype, but now I'm annoyed with the money we spent and my lingering craving for *good* Thai food.

I hate feeling like we should have just stayed home and eaten popcorn.
author: Shal J.

description:
Sadly, the time has come to move on from Ploy 2.   The Tom Kha was terrible and another *long* wait.  

Tonight I called in an order to pick up - my usual cold remedy: vegetables with silver noodles and tom kha prawn soup (don't remember the Thai word for prawns).  I was told my order would be ready for pick up in 10 minutes.  I arrived about 20 minutes later and then waited 15 minutes more until my order was ready. 

When I got home the first thing I opened was the soup, which by the way is not inexpensive at $8.95.  I have had tom kha soups from at least 30 establishments, including many in Thailand, and feel I have tried it all when it comes to this dish!  Ploy 2's has always been satisfactory (not great), but tonight it was unlike anything I've had before.  It had little chunks of what looked like curdled milk in it - I mean throughout the entire thing . . . something off with the coconut milk?  Something wrong with the temperature/cooking? I don't know, but I am amazed they actually let me take it home with me!!!  There's no way they couldn't have noticed.  The texture and appearance were so awful I couldn't eat it - even though the taste was okay.

I've been ordering food from Ploy 2 for about 5 years.  Generally the food is better than average, but I think I've kept going back, despite the fact that it takes anywhere from 50-90 minutes for food to be delivered, because the place is so damn cute and authentic.  But, there really is better food elsewhere - where the coconut milk isn't curdled and you don't have to wait so long for your order.  I'm sorry it's come to this . . . bye-bye Ploy 2 :(
author: eileen d.

description:
I just ate here, and it was pretty good. It does look like your going to someone's house, and it does look like they tried to squeeze in as many tables as they could.  Nevertheless, it was a good experience. 

We had the appetizer, Deep Fried Tofu with Peanut Sauce, kinda crunchy, but decent.  For dinner, it was the Chicken over spinach in Peanut Sauce.   Do you see a trend here? Anyhow, that was good. It was probably the sauce that made it tasty. The Chicken over mushrooms was good as well. Everything was finished, and there was nothing to complain about, which makes it a good experience. 

The price is good too. Two main dishes, an appetizer, and rice. All for $27 dollars. That's very reasonable. I would definitely go again.
author: Peter K.

description:
Went here last night with a group of 6. The place is upstair and I say it is not bad to look at. I had the spicy fish which was delicious, but a little more sauce would be nice. I like to drizzle it on my white rice. The white rice was harder than I would like. 
They don't serve all your food at the same time, which is good if you're with close friends (so they don't mind) and you're hungry.
The pumpkin curry was delicious. First they brought one with no curry at all, but we informed them and they gave us one with curry. The pad see ew and pad kee mow was okay. The BBQ chicken was nice and tender, it had a delicious light flavor.

I didn't try the papaya salad and green curry with beef, so I can't comment on that.

For dessert we had fried banana with coconut ice cream. It was very good. We also ordered sticky rice with mango, which was okay because the sticky rice was to mushy- it wasn't made correctly.

Overall it's a decent place, I would go here if I was in the neighborhood. I prefer going to Thai Time (Inner Richmond) or Tom Yum (Marina). But I am living in SF, gotta try different restaurants!!!
author: Chatree T.

description:
My favorite Thai place in the City!! As other Yelp-ers wrote, the place isn't fancy. It's up the stairs of an apartment-style space, but the Thai decor is authentic and if you sit by the window, you can people watch on Haight. Most importantly though, the food is the BOMB! 

Their curries are to die far - they're my favorite item on the menu. I've had the yellow and green curry which are both good but the best is the panang mango curry! This is always on their list of specials, and I've had it with chicken. Do yourself a favor and get the panang mango curry!

Their pad see ew is very good. When ordering delivery for this dish, I've found it's not as good as during sit-down. Other items I've had that I recommend (well there's nothing I don't recomment to be honest) include fried pumpin, tom kha, prik kring and some sauteed tofu dish that was to die for.

Their service isn't very good, but with how cheap the restaurant is for the quality of the food, I don't care and am not lowering a star based on the service this time.
author: Melissa C.

description: My favorite thai place in the city. The food is delicious and the service is reasonably quick with pretty nice staff. They do delivery, eat in, and take out. I recommend it highly if you are looking for a good reasonably priced thai place. They have a really extensive menu so you can try something new every time.
author: Ashley A.

description: I keep forgetting how close Ploy II is to Cha Cha Cha's! Almost kitty-corner. I wander Haight Street and the shop owners never know where it is. This is the best Thai I've found in CA so far. Incredibly fresh ingredients, flavorful, not so hot that you can't eat it. Tried the spicy duck in red curry special this time, killer. My friend and I shared the Tom Kha soup and wished we had more even though we each had a bowl and a half. The narrow entry from the street makes Ploy II easy to miss, the restaurant is at the top of the stairs. Look for the green sign up high. This place is funky and tight - it IS the Haight after all!
author: Ellen M.

description:
Our dinner here really sucked.  The Tom Kha soup seemed like it had been used to boil numerous chickens all day ... our bowl had that nasty white foam that is supposed to be skimmed off.  

We had to send the Pad Kee Mow back.  There is no way in hell it was fresh.  Some of the noodles were so dry they were crunchy ... and not pan-fried crunchy.  Crunchy and dried out like yesterday's uncovered leftovers.
author: T T.

description: This hands down one of the best Thai places in the entire city. Certainly the best in the Haight area. The service is slow, but that's because everything is cooked to order. I've given up on Pad Thai at other Thai places (usually soggy and gross), but here it's a fresh, noodley explosion of goodness. The Panang curries are also amazing. Basically, everything is good. The atmosphere is great too. Calm and quiet. Nice to be one floor above street level on Haight Street. For overall experience, if I had to pick one Thai place in the city to go to, this would be it.
author: Gabe R.

description: We would get delivery at least once a week - and enjoyed it as a decent Thai place.  I was going to rate it 3 stars until we found a long hair wrapped around our chicken satay.  Needless to say, that knocked it down and we threw the food away.  Hopefully they invest in hair nets for their cooks so other people don't have such a bad experience.
author: Van M.

description:
Consistantly good always and the women who work there are so sweet and nice.  It's a neighborhood favorite.  They've had a pumpkin appetizer on their specials menu for months and months now that is so good they really should just keep it forever, of course maybe that's why it's still a special.
A friend of mine says that they have the best green curry ever and I might be inclined to agree to this.  The panang curry shrimp with mango is excellent.
author: Gucci M.

description:
This place will save you from a hangover, from greasy, low quality, Thai food, and from your jaded "i hate the haight" self.  The atmosphere is homey, because the dining area is on the second floor of a Haight St Victorian.  The staff all wear vibrant, silk dresses and the rooms are adorned with lots of gold.  Service is a combination of friendly and curt.  The Tom Yum and Tom Kha are outstanding - hot and sour soups you crave when it's cold outside, or you need comfort inside.  Panang curry dishes all hit the mark with smooth coconut to soothe the good burn of the spices, but you'll pay the price in the WC the next day.  Som Tam, green papaya salad with peanuts, is an oral pleasure-journey through, tart, sweet, savory, nutty, and spicy.
Portions are hearty.  Prices are fair.  They are closed on Mondays, i.e. Siam Lotus day.
author: Michelina M.

description:
Have you  Ployed II?

Serious good Thai above your heads.  OK, its a funny place, a converted Victorian kitchen, and it all feel like it could tumble onto haight street in an earthquake.

But this is serious Thai. 

Best Picks: Vegetarian pad thai, or a pra ram.
author: Ken p.

description:
Miss Cat of Donuts - thanks for your recommendation...I headed to this place because my laptop had exactly 3 minutes of battery life left, and I needed to find a restaurant like now!

Cool atmosphere - its pretty much like you are eating in someone's house. At the same time, it isn't so overly romantic that you feel intimidated if you are a single guy walking in there randomly (like me!). 

Food was cool - I got the Pad See Ew, and an appetizer that had the word Prik (hehe) in the name...it was pretty much prawns wrapped up in egg roll wrappers, then deep fried. Good sauce with the appetizer - a little sweet, but not too sweet, and clearly not fake duck sauce like you get at lame chinese places since it was awesomely purple!

I can't say either dish blew me away, and I really thought my Pad See Ew could have used a lot more spice, but the balance was correct in both of the dishes - flavors didn't blurt each other out, and the whole sing sort of worked together in a super happy fun time of symphony.

The price was right - for both of the above and tea it was $20 after tip, and I had to roll out of that place I was so fraking full.
author: Sean C.

description:
We couldn't decide to have Thai or Caribbean food, but where drawn here by the doorway from the street. It is a charming little restaurant up above on the 2nd floor of an old building and has a small and somewhat intimate dining room but was perfect for a light lunch with some friends. 

Now about the food....we had an assortment of appetizers....my favorite being the fried tofu in peanut sauce. I had the chicken pad Thai which was good but needed a little extra kick of spiciness for my taste.....but hey for $7.95 it was all fine. Everything we had was "good" but nothing was amazing or stand out stellar.
author: Angela C.

description: Delicious food, quick service, polite servers.  One of my favorite places for Thai food in the city.  Try the mango curry!
author: S P.

description: Ploy II has some good food.  I have had food delivered and I have dined at the location.  The food is always fresh and the service is good.
author: Arron F.

description: Very small restaurant but real good thai homecooking! I had the pad se ew and my roomie had the pad thai.. The pad thai was a little sweet but it was still good when we added some chili sauce. The pad se ew was perfect with fried egg and plenty of beef and broccoli.
author: Kimberly P.

description: The drunken noodles were too greasy, but the mango prawn curry was superb.  It is great to have the option of brown rice.  The place is packed on Saturday night, so be prepared to wait or come to pick up your takeout order.  Will definitely try again to sample other dishes.
author: Yevgenia F.

description: Sorry I had a stomach ache after I had the soup. Won't be hitting this spot when I return unless it's to grab some spring rolls Togo. Cool location if your looking to empress a first timer.
author: Defa D.

description:
My favorite thing on the menu is the spicy tofu combination. Their little crispy fried rolls are also delicious. The servings are plentiful and prices are inexpensive. Be sure to check out the specials posted on the wall, too. And save room for fried bananas with coconut ice cream!

Sure, the decor is a little kitschy and the beer and wine selections are very limited. But as other reviewers mentioned, it's got a couple of nice big windows overlooking Haight Street -- perfect for discreet people-watching while you dine.
author: chocovore s.

description:
We live in Cole Valley and thought for dining our options are mainly in inner sunset...well we are learning that's not the case. This Thai place is great!

Excellent food, good service and let's face it cheapest house wine ever...well it's not the best but it's definitely good enough. I'm so thankful for all the yelpers review that got us to try this, now we go there twice a month minimum.

Pad Thai and Spicy Calamari are our favorites there!

enjoy.
author: Bee N.

description: I ordered the spicy calamari, and it was quite good... nothing too extraordinary, but it did the trick. The place is kind of strange to me, it's in a house... I've never really seen that before. I was cramped between the wall and the table, and I'm 6'. The other person I was with was 6'3, and they still sat us next to the wall. The service was OK, and it was a bit pricey for what it was worth.
author: Ward A.

description:
This place is not the place to go if you want really tasty Thai food. We went here based on Yelp reviews and were sorely disappointed. The food was just okay, nothing amazing. The curries weren't that flavorful.

The restaurant is on the second floor of a little place on Haight. It's a really cute interior, a bit cramped, but this is part of the charm. Unfortunately they put us at the worst possible table. I'm not sure who thought it was a good idea to put a table literally in front of a door, but I'm pretty sure it's against fire code and no one has been able to enjoy a meal in this spot. One of the chairs has its back out the doorway, and the other chair hangs into the kitchen doorway. Not cool.

The funny part of the evening was watching the matron of the restaurant take a dish away from the people next to us. She had given them someone else's appetizers by mistake and came back to snatch it away. The shocked guy still had his fork in the air. Priceless.

Needless to say, I will continue searching for a decent Thai place and will take Yelp reviews with a grain of salt.
author: Alison K.

description:
I have been to quite a few thai places in the city and Ploy is by far my favorite so far.  

Service:  Brief, semi-attentive, and helpful if needed.  The staff is not going to go out of their way to make friends with you but they get the job done, and the food more than makes up for it.

Drinks:  They serve the usual, but their wine and beer list is kinda bland and limited in selection.  They have this drink called coconut water though that is completely amazing, especially on hot days. (and they even serve it in a coconut!)  Also, I find a cold Budweiser to be an awesome paring with the curry because it's not a strong flavored beer and its clean cold finish compliments the strong spice of the dishes.

Food:   I've liked everything I have ever ordered here except for the fried rice.  My personal favorites have to be the spicy prawns and the Chicken Curry (extra spicy).  I reccomend ordering the curries without the sweet basil though, as it can be overwhelming.  The chicken curry was so good I had it twice in one week.  The dishes flavor has a way of staying with you for a day or two after you eat there.  Kinda like Naan n' Curry but not so intense. MMMM.  I think i'll eat at ploy for lunch tommorow.

Good luck and good eating.
author: Nick L.

description:
This is my favorite Thai restaurant in the city; the food is absolutely delicious and reasonably priced, and you can usually find a table at Ploy II when nearby restaurants are packed full.  Why is that?  It could be the entrance so subtle you could almost miss it, or the fact that it is upstairs in a converted Victorian home and the decor makes you feel like you are dining at your grandmother's place.

Whatever it is, I'm happy the rest of the city hasn't overrun this gem of a restaurant yet.  The red pumpkin curry is my favorite dish - it's just perfect, and runner up is the spicy prawns with basil and bamboo shoots which is always fresh and full of flavor.  They also have a good vegetarian menu and don't forget to try the Thai iced tea!
author: Simon B.

description:
Note: review on delivery only.

same exact experience as Dave S. 
-lazy sunday night
-live a few blocks away
-called at 8, said it would be an hour.
-called at 9:15, just started cooking.
-it's 9:40, and I'm writing this review and not eating. 

if anything, they get points for consistency. 

Advice: if they quote you an hour, you may want to call at the 45 min mark to remind them to start cooking. Then prepare to wait another 30...
author: Sanky P.

description:
If i didn't know better, I would have thought I was Joe L (see his review).  I too ordered delivery on a Friday night and also live around NOPA.  I was told it would be 45 minutes, but after after an Hour and a Half, I had to call.  I was told that it would be 10 minutes.  40 minutes after that the guy showed up.

It is really a shame, because they have delicious Thai, but 2 hours is pretty ridiculous.  If you can't get your delivery out in a reasonable time, just say you don't deliver, and be done with it.  Again, good food, but I would steer clear of getting delivery from this place.
author: Brian S.

description:
The only reason I am not rating this with 5 stars is because it is very short of space, which causes it too seem crowded even during non-peak hours. However, I don't believe it is there fault since San Francisco has extremely high rent cost and is the second most dense city in the United States. They make the most of their space and still have great customer service. The staff is polite and easy to communicate with. The restaurant seems like it was at one point a home or apartment building. 
Thai food is very delicious especially when the vegetables and herbs are prepared the right way. If you life freshness, this is the place for you. My cousin attended the University of San Francisco and when I crossed the bay to visit we would almost always go here or order take out. The location is perfect. Haight-Ashbury is full of tourist and locals and most important, culture. I seriously recommend visiting this small Thai restaurant if you are in the area.
author: Garrett G.

description: Amazing food! Best Thai food I've had in San Francisco! I had the food delivered, so I don't know about service or ambiance, but they seemed very nice on the phone.
author: Amy M.

description:
What can I say about my beloved Ploy that won't have you convinced I've got stock in the company? Thai is my favourite kind of food, so treating myself to a meal at Ploy was always going to make me happy, because the food was always delicious. The restaurant itself is in an old Edwardian house, so the atmosphere was lovely. Nice for first dates or big parties, and yes, I've had both there.


 My favourite place to eat their food, though, was in the comfort of my own home, luckily just down the street, so it was always nice and hot. One of my closest friends and I would order as much as we could carry and scurry home, and indulge in a meal where there was never much uttered other than the occasional mmmmm, or oh, this is SOOOO good! : )
author: Laurelei

description:
Yes and yes...after making the mistake of going to Citrus Club...I went to Ploy II and all was right in the  world. 
Bright, light, clean, kind service and.....DELICIOUS!!
Thanks, PLOY II you are a true diamond on the Haight.

The Panang Curry is delish....KeeMao fans its on the fans as #9 Spicy Noodles.
author: Honey L.

description:
Okay, so my friend decided to show me his "secret place." He took me to Ploy II. Now it's my "secret place" too :) . I loved this place. It's inside a 2-story house. You come upstairs, and WHOA, it's a restaurant! This place is always crowded and I understand why :) . One of the best Thai places in San Francisco! 
We ordered vegetarian Tom Kha, chicken Larb, mixed sauteed seafood, and a side of steamed rice. 
The soup is yummy - nice and rich, with veggies and pieces of fried tofu - and  with a pouch of sweetness from coconut milk ^_^ .
Larb is an absolute must-try. It's a meat salad made with ground chicken and mint. Yep, the secret ingredient is the mint, um-num-num.
The star of our dinner that the mixed  seafood plate. Best of the best. Sauteed calamari rings, octopus, pieces of with fish, and shrimp. Served with salad. I loved this from my first bite. Rich and salty, and melts in your mouth.
The bill came to about $32, which is not bad for this amount of food. 
We left totally satisfied! :) .
author: ponch l.

description: One more vote for the Mango prawn curry, very unique and delicious. Beyond that dish just about everything I've had at Ploy is great, and the prices are very reasonable.
author: Dave C.

description: The quality of the food is amazing.  The wait staff is very friendly and the chef was very accommodating to my vegan diet.  Who knew that Thai Iced Tea with coconut milk would taste so delicious?!
author: Alvin M.

description:
We just moved to the Haight and were pleasantly surprised by Ploy II.
